DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF RT HON. F. M. FORDE

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform honourable senators that on 28 January 1983 a former Prime Minister of Australia, the Right Honourable F. M. Forde, passed away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 28 January 1983 of the Right Honourable Francis Michael Forde, a member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Capricornia from 1922 to 1946, a former Prime Minister and Minister of the Crown, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

It is with regret that I inform the Senate of the death of the Right Honourable Frank Forde on 28 January this year. Mr Forde was a Prime Minister of this country for a very brief period indeed, but his great contribution to this country was made in a variety of spheres of public life, particularly in politics. He had a long and distinguished career of service to both his nation and to the Australian Labor Party.

I am sure a number of honourable senators on both sides of the House will remember seeing him in King's Hall only a year or two ago, aged about 90 and still of apparently sound health and certainly of good mind. His achievements in the political arena are often overshadowed by his short period as Prime Minister , which I have referred to, after the death of John Curtin. His career in public life began in 1917 and ended in 1957.

He was born at Mitchell in Queensland and educated at the Christian Brothers College in Toowoomba. Prior to being elected to the Queensland Legislative Assembly in 1917 he worked in the Postmaster-General's Department. He was in the Queensland Parliament until 1922 and then subsequently came to Canberra as the member for the electoral division of Capricornia. During his time in Canberra he served as a Minister in the Scullin Government, first as Assistant Minister for Trade and Customs and then as Minister, and also Acting Minister for Markets and Transport. When he died he was the last surviving member of the Scullin Ministry . He served also in the Curtin Government, as Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for the Army, and in the Chifley Government, as Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for the Army. He was Deputy Leader of the Australian Labor Party from 1932 until his defeat in 1946.

Frank Forde, like all of us, suffered some of the ups and downs in politics. I was reminded this morning by a historian of these matters that in 1946 Frank Forde had, as his campaign slogan, a picture of himself with General MacArthur. The caption read: 'Frank Forde and General MacArthur-two men of destiny'. Frank Forde lost his seat in that election. It is significant to recall that he was, as a Minister at that time, very much associated with the defence of Australia. He served, of course, in other capacities, such as a delegate to various international bodies, and after his defeat as a member of the Federal Parliament he re-entered the Queensland Parliament until his defeat in 1957.

Mr Forde is survived by three daughters and a daughter-in-law. I attended his funeral as a representative of the then Opposition. It was an occasion at which there was a degree of contentment and satisfaction at his great contribution to public life. There was a great sense of community at the funeral because he was very much a man of his community. It was an occasion, perhaps, for rejoicing, rather than great sadness, at the life which Frank Forde led. I have had pleasure in moving the motion which I moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I have pleasure in seconding and supporting, the motion which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Senator Button has already outlined to the Senate Frank Forde's parliamentary career at both the national and State levels. The peak of that career was, of course, his becoming Prime Minister, although for a relatively brief period, in July 1945. In some respects it is perhaps unfortunate that Mr Forde appears to be best known today because of the relatively brief time that he served as Prime Minister. This tends to downgrade the very important role he played in Australian politics, particularly in the political history of the Australian Labor Party over a long period. The fact is that he contributed to public life in Australia for a total of 32 years in both the Queensland and the national parliaments.

SPEECH.PARA: His service as a Minister in the Commonwealth Government could not have occurred at a more demanding time in our nation's history. As a member of the War Cabinet between October 1941 and January 1946-for almost 2 1/2 years of that time, serving as Army Minister and Deputy Prime Minister-he was part of a small group of people whose responsibility it was to guide Australia through its gravest external crisis. Obviously, he had to shoulder a very heavy burden of leadership. Of course, he carried a particularly demanding portfolio during wartime.

In remembering Frank Forde, we pay due regard to the contribution he made to his country outside those days when he assumed the highest elected office. It is obvious from reading about Mr Forde that he was a man of great courtesy, decency and generosity. The real test of any person-particularly a politician because of the public nature of our existence-is how he or she handles the disappointments and setbacks which afflict us all from time to time. As the man who was in the forefront of Labor politics for such a long period, he must naturally have wanted to attain, and retain, the prime ministership. Yet he had to suffer a tantalisingly close loss to John Curtin in a ballot for party leader in 1932 and then, 13 years later, he saw his colleagues opt for Ben Chifley as Labor Prime Minister. It is worth noting what Chifley's biographer, Professor Crisp, had to say about Frank Forde's reaction to the caucus vote which elected the new leader in July 1945. Forde made, according to Crisp, a 'simple, graceful and-in the bitterly disappointing circumstances-courageous speech of congratulations'. As far as Curtin was concerned he never had any doubts about Frank Forde's standing in the nation's history, describing him as the best Prime Minister Australia has had.

Mr President, the Liberal Party in this place joins with the Government in paying tribute to Frank Forde as a parliamentarian, Labor Party Leader, high commissioner and Prime Minister, and extends its sympathy to the surviving members of his family.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

—On behalf of the Opposition I also express the sympathy of the Opposition to the families and friends of the deceased ex-members and ex-senators who have been named here today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the remarks of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in expressing sympathy to the families of the people mentioned. I express the sympathy of my party particularly to the family of the late former Senator Ted Maher, who had very long experience in parliaments, both in Queensland and in this chamber. Indeed, he had a very long lifetime. He was 92 years old. He had a varied background. He was born in Forbes in New South Wales and educated in Forbes and Grenfell. As I live between those two towns, I am sure that he spent his early years in two very fine communities. He served for many years in the Postmaster-General's Department in Sydney and in a number of country towns. He was a member of a stock and station agency. He served with the International Harvester Co., as I recall, in Sydney, Perth and Brisbane. He did all these things before he started a 20-year service in the Parliament of Queensland, followed by no less than 16 years in the Australian Senate. He served on the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and on the Public Works Committee. The late former Senator Maher was a sincere and popular figure who served his country and his community well. I express the sympathy of especially my party and myself to those whom he has left behind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pay tribute to Adair Macalister Blain, who was first elected as member for the Northern Territory in 1934. Adair Macalister Blain was a most unusual person and gave much to his country in peace and war. It is of interest to note that he succeeded Mr H. G. Nelson, who was the father of Mr Jock Nelson. Mr H. G. Nelson was the first member for the Northern Territory. Then came Adair Macalister Blain, who was defeated in 1949 by Mr Jock Nelson. Adair Macalister Blain served for 15 years as an independent member of the House of Representatives before he was defeated in 1949. He was a surveyor by profession and served in the Army too. While he was a surveyor he carried out an expedition into western Arnhem Land. He also carried out official surveys into the Barkly Tableland and The Granites field. Of course, in the early 1930s this put him into the category of explorer, in which he carried out considerable work.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also of interest to note that he joined the Australian Imperial Force in 1916 and served with the 32nd Battalion. He was wounded in action in 1918 and his appointment in the Army was terminated on 31 December 1919. As I said, later as the official surveyor in northern Australia he carried out various expeditions. He enlisted again, which means that he served in both world wars. He served in 1940 in the Second Australian Imperial Force. He was a prisoner of war from February 1942 to August 1945. He was in Changi, Sandakan, Kuching and Outram Road prisons. It is interesting to note that in 1943, while he was a prisoner of war, he was re-elected to the House of Representatives. He returned to Australia in 1945. After a distinguished service to Parliament and to the nation he returned to surveying in 1955. I, as a child and a youth, knew Adair Blain. He was a most notable person. He gave much to the outback and to the north.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Vietnam Veterans
To the honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
2. many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
3. Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
4. the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Declaration Form
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the requirement that pensioners and health care cardholders fill in a complex declaration when presenting prescriptions is causing distress to beneficiaries and inefficiencies in the distribution of medicines by pharmacists .
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Government will immediately abolish the requirement that a declaration be completed by the pensioner and health care cardholder.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Tate (from 8,782 citizens) and Robertson (from 1,122 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your Petitioners do not want a Uranium Enrichment Plant constructed in South-East Queensland because:
(a) there is no known way of safely storing uranium waste products;
(b) there has not been an environment impact study conducted into the effects of such a Uranium Enrichment Plant;
(c) Australia has adequate coal supplies to provide energy for industry;
(d) the risks to local inhabitants from the operation of such a plant have not been established;
(e) the products of such a plant will contribute to the prospect of nuclear war ;
(f) the local area would become a target in the event of such a nuclear war;
(g) the investment in such a Uranium Enrichment Plant would be better spent in research into clean, renewable energy sources such as solar energy.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
(a) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on the export of pro- ducts from Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(b) reject all applications for the export of products from Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(c) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on foreign investment in Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(d) reject all applications for foreign investment in Uranium Enrichment Plants ;
(e) do all in the Senate's power to prevent the construction of a Uranium Enrichment Plant in South-East Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised- that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer, profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst, pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing therefore, your petitioners urge that:
(1) All pensions and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the national average male earnings seasonally adjusted.
(2) Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973.
Reintroduction of Medibank in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

(3) To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government immediately inject $ 200 million into State housing authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In light of the critical role of wage levels in determining employment levels, can the Minister inform the Senate precisely what view will be adopted by the Government before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with respect to such vital questions as wage catch-up and future wage adjustment generally over the next year?

—The present Government had a commitment prior to the election, and has now, to ensure that there is a centralised wage fixation system in Australia contrary to the chaotic system that existed between 1981 and December 1982 under the previous Government. Questions of wage levels will be determined by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission as they always have been, but the Commonwealth will be putting a view to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is not my intention at this stage-the matter not having been finalised-to foreshadow the details of the Commonwealth's submission. I should say in answering the question that the Government, since it assumed office, has urged upon all sections of the community the necessity for restraint in the current chaotic economic circumstances which we have inherited. Part of that restraint will relate to the wage-earning section of the community. Discussions on that subject have consistently taken place with the Australian Council of Trade Unions since we assumed government and the ACTU now acknowledges the need for restraint in a manner which it was not prepared to adopt in previous years.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Does the Government regard a 3 per cent to 4 per cent increase this year as an appropriate degree of restraint?

—The Government has indicated that it favours restraint. I think the simplicity of Senator Chaney's question can be answered only in terms of whether one is talking about restraint by the lowest paid workers in this community and whether it would be appropriate for them to receive a wage increase of some kind this year, or whether, on the other hand, one is talking about highly paid people in this community such as politicians. Those questions will be addressed by the Government before making its submission to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Government provides funds for the operations of the Tasmanian public hospital system, including the Royal Hobart Hospital, under certain cost-sharing arrangements with the State? Is the Minister aware of the resignation yesterday of the Chairman of the Royal Hobart Hospital Board in relation to which the Chairman is reported to have spoken of the charade of the 1982-83 budget preparation forced upon the hospital's Board by the State Minister for Health? He said that the exercise 'was a farce; it was ill-conceived, incapable of being implemented and accompanied by threats and intimidating statements'. What steps will the Commonwealth Government take to prevent these financial and other harassments from continuing to the untold damage of the Tasmanian public hospital system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was disturbed, as I am sure everybody else in Tasmania was, to find out this morning that Mr Kearney, the Chairman of the Board of the Royal Hobart Hospital, had resigned. I was even more disturbed to find out the circumstances under which he had resigned. I have an interest in this matter not only as a Tasmanian but also as an ex-employee of the Royal Hobart Hospital. I find it very disturbing to discover that this very fine hospital-it still is a very fine hospital which has served this community very well-is in the state it is in. Not only the fact that the Chairman of the Board has felt he should resign worries us--
—You don't know the full circumstances.
—I find that the circumstances under which he resigned, as outlined in his letter, should disturb all of us.
—Not the full circumstances.
—As Senator Walters is so interested I think we should look at some of the remarks made by Mr Kearney, particularly--
—A very distinguished Tasmanian, I believe.

—A very distinguished Tasmanian, a Tasmanian who has been asked by governments of both persuasions to conduct inquiries into such things as technical education in Tasmania and tertiary education. He is a former registrar of the university and a man who, in the past, has not hesitated to criticise governments of all persuasions in bringing down his reports. In his letter of resignation to the Honourable T. J. Cleary, the Minister for Health, he had some disturbing things to say. For instance, he said that the Board and the hospital had been subject to financial and other harassment ill-befitting a board with such responsibilities. He pointed out that the Department of Health in Tasmania, without any prior consultation or warning to any hospital in the State, had produced an entirely new procedure for determining budget allocations, making it impossible for these hospitals to plan properly. He summarised the State Government's budgeting methods by saying:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the initial provisional budget exercised by the Government was a farce; it was ill-conceived, incapable of being implemented and accompanied by threats and intimidating statements.

His five-page letter is an indictment of the operations of the Government in Tasmania of which Senator Walters is so proud. Tasmanian hospitals are funded under a Commonwealth-State hospitals agreement which still applies in Tasmania to the extent of 50 per cent funding by the State and 50 per cent by the Commonwealth. Of course, the Commonwealth is concerned about these matters. The Commonwealth cannot directly interfere in these matters. All it can do is seek some guidance from the State Government as to just what it is about and hope that the State Government in fact wakes up to itself in its treatment of State hospitals but, in particular, the Royal Hobart Hospital, so that we do not have the situation where distinguished citizens have to resign their positions and have to use the sort of language that Mr Kearney has had to use to describe the shambles in which Mr Cleary, Mr Gray and his colleagues have left our hospital system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I ask: Is there consensus between the Government and the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Dolan, on his statement today that wage restraint did not mean that the wages pause should continue into the distant future? Mr Dolan further stated that there is an expectation that the 2.2 per cent consumer price index rise of last week will be received by wage and salary earners. He said that it is an example of increases not influenced by wage movements. I would like a clear statement from the Government on its attitude with regard to the recent consumer price index increase.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's question related to the extension of the wages pause. I have not seen Mr Dolan's statement but I understand he said that it should not be continued into the distant future. Certainly there is consensus between the Government and the ACTU on that question. The wages pause should not be continued into the distant future. With regard to any statement made by Mr Dolan in relation to the 2.2 per cent consumer price index increase for March, I am unable to make any comment about the details of Mr Dolan's statement. The Government has not determined any attitude to that question.

ANSWER.PARA: Needless to say, a program has been set in train for the approach to the fixation of wages this year in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which is where that issue belongs. A conference has already been held between the parties and a further conference will be held at the end of May in relation to wage fixation procedures for this year. When the question of appropriate wage levels comes before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission by way of a hearing, the Commonwealth will make a submission in relation to that matter. The 2.2 per cent CPI increase will, of course, be taken into account in considering the contents of that submission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General. How does the Minister respond to the continuing problems faced by the typists employed in the Victorian State office of the Commonwealth Reporting Service arising from the previous Government's arbitrary policy of shifting Victorian-generated work to other transcription centres interstate? Can the Government give the casual typists of the Melbourne Commonwealth Reporting Service an undertaking that the current allocation of work away from Victoria will be reviewed in the near future? On a broader point, can the Minister assure the Senate that the work of the Commonwealth Reporting Service, as well as that of all the other areas of employment in the Attorney-General's Department, will be arranged without political prejudice against any one particular State, as appears to have been the policy of the previous Government?

—I am indebted to my colleague for his question, genuinely without notice, on this matter. It is one close to my heart, having pursued this over the last months of last year with a number of representations to my predecessor in this office. I am afraid all I can say to him about the conduct of the typing operations of the Commonwealth Reporting Service is that I have asked for a full review from my Department on that question with a view to establishing exactly why these decisions about work allocations interstate were made and with a view, of course, to redressing the situation in the event that there proves to be, as I suspect, no rational logistical foundation for those particular decisions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General often referred to or described the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union- the Costigan Commission-as a 'de facto crimes commission'? Has he seen, listened to, or read a transcript of the Four Corners program of last Saturday in which allegations were made concerning a conspiracy to pervert the course of justice by the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran, and an association between a former Chief Stipendiary Magistrate, Mr Murray Farquhar, and a Mr George Freeman, who was named as being one of the leaders in organised crime in New South Wales by the Moffitt Royal Commission? The allegations in the program included a charge that Mr Farquhar misused his office in the committal hearings of a Mr Kevin Humphreys.

QUESTION.PARA: Without canvassing the innocence or guilt of any of the persons named, but because two arms of the New South Wales Government, namely, the judiciary and the executive, have been accused of being possible co-conspirators to pervert the course of justice, does the Attorney-General not agree that it would be singularly inappropriate for these allegations to be tested or heard by any instrument of government or the judiciary in New South Wales? Because of this, will the Attorney-General consider referring the allegations and the whole question to the Costigan Royal Commission? At the same time, will he consider referring allegations made against a former Premier of New South Wales, Sir Robert Askin, concerning connections with organised crime in Sydney and, in particular, the specific charges made about him in the National Times of 13 to 27 September 1981 in which, inter alia, it was stated that Sir Robert Askin received $100,000 for almost eight years from a close confederate of Mr George Freeman, Mr Perc Galea? In conclusion, if the Attorney-General cannot give me a reply to these questions today, will he undertake to make a statement concerning these matters before the end of the week?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before the Attorney-General answers the question, I advise the Senate that I have been informed that legal proceedings have been taken in the matter. I am allowing the question but whether it is a matter within the jurisdiction of the Attorney-General to answer is a question for him alone.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be well known that in this place I have never taken the view that the mere issue of a defamation writ is sufficient in itself to make a matter sub judice and as such beyond the capacity of the Parliament to debate in any respect whatsoever. But at the same time, I think rather more respect ought to be paid to the judicial institutions of New South Wales than has been the case in the asking of Senator Chipp's question. I certainly would not seek to pre-empt in anything I said, here or elsewhere, what is now properly before the judicial institutions of that State. There is no question of my referring to the Costigan Commission any of the matters to which Senator Chipp referred. I say that because, as Senator Chipp ought to be well aware, the brief of the Costigan Commission is to deal only with matters that could possibly amount to breaches of either Commonwealth law or Victorian law because the Commonwealth and Victorian governments are the governments that have issued the commissions in question. Although, in a sense, it is the case that the Costigan Commission has in recent times been acting as a de facto crimes commission because of the extraordinary tentacles of the original actions of painters and dockers that it was investigating, nonetheless every matter which the Costigan Commission is now investigating has a link of a direct or indirect kind back to the activities of the painters and dockers. I do not understand from anything that Senator Chipp has said or alleged that there is any such suggestion in this case.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not honestly think that I can add anything useful to this matter; it is one for the administration of justice in New South Wales. I simply express my complete confidence in the integrity of the New South Wales Premier and am quite sure that when this matter is finally resolved to everybody's satisfaction it will be evident that there is no foundation whatsoever for the allegations that have been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Attorney-General for his answer, particularly for guiding me towards the necessity for a link between certain allegations and Commonwealth responsibility . In light of that, does the Attorney agree that trafficking illegally in drugs is a matter of proper concern to the Commonwealth? Is he not aware that Mr George Freeman, who was mentioned in the allegations made in the Four Corners program, has been mentioned in at least one Federal or State royal commission inquiring into the trafficking of illegal drugs? Will the Attorney-General look again at my question and see whether he can establish that link and come to a conclusion that allegations as serious as this, when they include people such as Freeman, have in fact a link with Commonwealth responsibilities?
—If Senator Chipp wishes to embark upon a fishing expedition, that is entirely his prerogative. I have no wish to join him in that expedition.

—My question also is directed to the Attorney-General and relates to the Australian Constitutional Convention held in Adelaide last week. I ask: First, is the Attorney-General aware that many of the reports that were produced by bipartisan committees of the Convention were overturned at the Convention? Secondly, was this the result of the Federal Liberals abandoning previously agreed positions and also of the stacking of delegations by Queensland and Tasmania? Thirdly, is he aware of reports that at a meeting of the Liberal Party of Australia Federal and State leaders that took place just hours before the Convention was opened it was decided that a deliberate assault should be mounted on the Labor Government's policy of consensus in the hope that opposition to most proposals put forward at the Convention would be seen by the Australian people as the breakdown of consensus? Fourthly, can he advise whether the Labor Government's policy for consensus and real constitutional reform is still alive and kicking despite the calculated attempts of the Liberal Party to destroy it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that a number of matters that were before last week's Constitutional Convention had previously been the subject of long, detailed and very constructive analysis and report by standing committees of the Constitutional Convention over a long period and that those reports were in most respects last week treated cavalierly, with disdain and rather disgracefully by a number of the delegates in question. More particularly it is the case that a number of agenda items as to which prior notice had been given by particular delegates on behalf of particular delegations and on which delegates or delegations in question had taken clear and unequivocal public positions in advance were the subject of fairly spectacular retreat on the floor of the Convention, nowhere more so than in the case of Senator Durack and his family law proposal, which he himself had given notice of a few weeks before the Constitutional Convention.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the case that at least two of the delegations to last week's Constitutional Convention were blatantly and unashamedly stacked. It is the case that the Commonwealth delegation of 16 was divided equally between government and non-government delegations. It is equally the case that the New South Wales, Victorian, South Australian and West Australian delegations, all led of course by Labor Party government leaders, were divided equally, six all, as between non -government and government members. It is also the case that the Bjelke-Petersen -led delegation from Queensland was in fact sent to the Convention on the basis of nine government members and only three positions being made available to the Opposition. Quite naturally, the Australian Labor Party boycotted the Convention on that basis. It is also the case that the Tasmanian delegation contained only two members of the Labor Party out of 12.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many Liberals? Come on.
—It contained four paid-up and practising members of the Liberal Party.
—That is not the truth.

—I am giving the full and absolute truth of the matter, if the Senate will listen. There were 12 Tasmanian delegates. They were divided into seven from the lower House and five from the upper House. The five upper House delegates were all 'Independents' in the Tasmanian tradition and in every instance that I can recall voted with the conservative majority on the floor of the Conference. Of the seven lower House delegate positions, which it was squarely within the capacity of the Gray Government to command and to divide equally and appropriately between the parties, four were taken by the Gray Government for its own members, leaving two for the Labor Party and one for the Independent in the lower House, Doug Lowe.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the truth of the matter. It would have been very easy indeed for Tasmania, given its peculiar position in the upper House, to do as the Western Australian Government honourably did under Sir Charles Court at previous conventions. There has been a long tradition in Western Australia until now, because of the gerrymander in the upper House, of an overwhelming preponderance of non-government members in that House. In past years, prior to the present Convention, the delegation from Western Australia has been divided into seven members from the lower House and five from the upper House and the preponderance of the delegates from the upper House, reflecting the composition of that House in Western Australia, has been non-government. But under the Court Government-I hope people on the other side of the chamber will listen to this-it was the case , even when the Liberals were in power, for the lower House delegation of seven members to be divided into four and three in favour of the Australian Labor Party, then in opposition, in order to balance that uneven state of affairs in the upper House. That was an honourable course to adopt, consistent with the high aspirations and objectives of the Constitutional Convention.

That was the kind of convention that had developed about the conduct of the Constitutional Convention over the 10 years of its operation. Those were the conventions that, once again, were torn up by the people on the other side of this chamber and their colleagues in other States, particularly Queensland and Tasmania, who, always demonstrate their utter inability to match their sentiments with their performance whenever they get the opportunity. I was asked about reports that this state of affairs on the floor of the Convention had been deliberately contrived. It is the case that Mr Bill Goff of the Australian Associated Press, in an AAP news feature put on the public record on 1 May, said :

According to one well-placed, non-Labor convention source the whole sad episode had its genesis in a deliberate decision taken by the meeting of Liberal Party, Federal and State leaders in Adelaide just hours before the Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, opened the conference on Tuesday night.

There is then some evidence, put on the record by a reputable journalist, from a source which he does not name although he clearly identifies where he comes from , that the whole exercise and the way in which the convention conducted itself were a deliberate attempt to break down the atmosphere of consensus and reconciliation which we have all been trying so hard to achieve. It was a deliberate attack on the traditions of the Convention and a deliberate attempt to undermine any constructive achievement by it.

Finally, I was asked whether the constitutional review process could possibly be described as alive and well in the light of those events. Clearly, that cannot be said to be the case any longer. I and the Labor Government remain firmly committed to the process of constitutional review. All honourable senators on this side of the chamber and this Government remain firmly committed to rational debate on constitutional reform matters. But as long as the sorts of things take place as occurred last week in the lead-up to the Convention, in the composition of delegations and on the floor of the Convention, it will be simply impossible for the Commonwealth Government to continue its support for the Convention process in its present form.

Mr President, Ben Chifley once said in a very famous quotation, which I hope you will forgive me for putting on the public record: 'The trouble with gentlemen's agreements is that there are not enough bloody gentlemen'. That was amply demonstrated to be the case on the floor of that Convention last week. Unless the other side of politics in this country lifts its collective game I am afraid we are in for a very unhappy time indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney- General a question with respect to the representation of States at constitutional conventions. Is it not a fact that at the last two conventions the Liberal Party and National Party had nine of the 12 delegates and the Australian Labor Party had three delegates and at the preceding two conventions Labor had only two delegates from Queensland? Is it not also a fact that there were five Labor members in each of the Tasmanian State delegations until the last Convention and that the imbalance on the last occasion was in part caused by the fact that two delegates resigned from the Labor Party and became Independents just before the Convention?

—Out of Senator Chaney's own mouth comes the clear admission that the delegations were unequally balanced as between government and non- government members in Tasmania and Queensland at this Convention and indeed at two earlier conventions. I readily concede that that has been the case over the last three conventions. It is a puzzling logic, however, that Senator Chaney should somehow rely on a breach of practice over a significant period as in any way justifying what was done on this occasion. On each occasion it was done under protest from the Australian Labor Party members of the delegations in question who nonetheless took--
—It was not.
—That is certainly the case in relation to Queensland. I would believe anything so far as Tasmania was concerned.
—A continuity of corruption was favoured.

—As the Leader of the Government in the Senate says, a continuity of corruption seems to be favoured now by the Leader of the Opposition. The fact that the delegations have been composed in this way in the past in no way undermines the force of the contention that we advance on this occasion and which we have been advancing for a long time now; that is, the only way forward-if we are to talk seriously about constitutional review in this country-is if we put aside some of these partisan differences that divide us and try to find a constructive, common ground. These matters are not going to be achieved by numerical resolution on the floor of conventions. It will not be by simple majority votes and narrow majority victories that constitutional reform achievements are made but by a process of consensus building across party lines, which is simply not going to be advanced by the kind of behaviour to which Senator Chaney seems now totally wedded.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that the earlier delegations were established under Labor governments in Tasmania and reflected the balance of the political forces in Tasmania at that time and that the practice was continued by the present Government?

—That is not my understanding of the situation. The situation in the upper House then was that the Independents were balanced, as I understand it, rather differently in terms of their practical orientation than the way they were balanced on this particular occasion. I appreciate that it is a matter of some subtlety to identify the different shades of ideological opinion within the Tasmanian upper House; it is a matter of very considerable subtlety indeed. Nonetheless, if one approaches that task of analysis with the appropriate instruments, one can in fact discern that what happened on this occasion was a far more blatantly contrived and stacked final result than has been the situation in the past.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Has any investigation been done, or is any proposed, about the possible effects on interest rates of the tax on bank debits, especially in the light of people choosing already to close their cheque accounts and transfer their funds to interest bearing or savings accounts? Further, has any investigation been done, or is any proposed, about the possible effects on such people as pensioners, particularly disabled pensioners, whose incomes and expenses are currently managed by cheques precisely because of the convenience of cheque accounts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Minister for Finance announced that this policy of the previous Government would be continued by the present Government, he also announced that it would be reviewed in six months to see what changes, if any, would be made. As to the second part of Senator Crowley's question, the degree, if any, to which current account deposits are run down because of the introduction of this tax should be apparent within a few months with the publication of the statistics of the Reserve Bank of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I might add in closing that the idle balances held in current accounts declined very substantially over the previous couple of years due to the record high interest rates inflicted on the country by the previous Government. The record high interest rates, rising on the short term market to above 20 per cent from time to time, which the Fraser Government inflicted on Australia had already induced a substantial number of people either to close current accounts or reduce substantially the idle balance being held therein. Whether this transactions tax induces a further run-down in the balances held in current accounts will, as I said earlier, be known within a few months with the publication of the Reserve Bank statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I understand that the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs instituted a full inquiry into the manufacture and supply of artificial limbs. Is the current Minister's decision to stop the entry of new manufacturers into the field a result of the report of that inquiry and his consideration of it? If so, would the Minister table the report itself for the benefit of the whole range of interested persons inside and outside the Parliament?

—The honourable sena- tor asked me a question in respect of the government organised system that allows for the provision of artificial limbs for not only ex-service men and women but also members of the community. As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, a considerable proportion of the activity was transferred to the private sector. Last week I answered a question about this matter addressed to me by Senator Childs. A report was provided to me that suggested that the costs involved in the transfer of a considerable proportion of this activity to the private sector would be 30 per cent higher than the current costs. As I believe that that report was a factual one prepared by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, I have no hesitation, of course, in making that information available to the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. Are candidates for the House of Representatives required to certify in any way that, if elected, they will carry out their duties as elected representatives? Have any calculations been made to determine the cost to the taxpayers of the by-elections in Wannon and Bruce brought about by the resignations of the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, only 26 days after the recent election, and Sir Billy Snedden, merely 47 days after being elected as the member for Bruce?
—If the calculations have not been done, no doubt they now will be, in the light of the encouragement given to me and the Minister by Senator Colston. I will refer the question to the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that a handicapped person is refused tax deductibility for the expense of having a person go to his home daily to assist him to get dressed, go out and about and, when necessary, keep appointments and take his place in the work force? Is the Minister aware that tax deductibility could be granted if the person who is employed in that situation is a registered nurse? As the nature of the assistance is totally physical and not medical, would the Minister agree that this is an anomalous situation? If so, will the Minister ask his colleague the Treasurer to review the matter and ensure that future guidelines are more flexible and equitable?

—My understanding of the situation is that that is correct. It was drawn to my attention some time ago. I am pleased that Senator Messner, now that he is the shadow Minister for Social Security, is taking an interest in matters in which the previous Government took no interest for the seven years that it was in power. I will certainly confirm that this anomaly exists, as I believe it does. I will seek assistance from the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance to overcome the anomaly. I also remind honourable senators that we have inherited from the previous Government a pilot project concerned with the investigation of establishing an attendant care scheme in this country, which may assist people in this situation.

—I refer the Attorney-General to the proposal put to the Australian Constitutional Convention last week to amend the Constitution to enable the Commonwealth Government to give the Family Court of Australia complete jurisdiction over the custody, guardianship and maintenance of children , and over matrimonial property. Was this proposal designed to ensure that all children, whatever the circumstances of their birth, and all matrimonial property issues, whether in connection with divorce or not, be within the jurisdiction of the court best qualified to deal with them? Was this proposal the very proposal which was placed on the Convention agenda by the former Attorney-General, Senator Durack, and which he would have moved with the support of his delegation had he still been Attorney-General at the time of the Convention? What explanation can the Minister offer for Senator Durack's somersault on this proposal, which resulted directly in the proposal not being passed and quite unnecessarily being referred to a standing committee?

—The proposal that came forward to the Convention was designed to rationalise the law relating to custody, maintenance and property disputes and to ensure that some of the quite heart-wrenching disputes that have occurred in recent times and have involved the juggling of matters of this kind backwards and forwards between multiple courts in both Federal and State jurisdictions did not in fact recur. Yes, this proposal was the exact same proposal which was placed on the Convention paper by the former Attorney-General , Senator Durack, and which he would undoubtedly have moved with the support of his delegation had he still been Attorney-General. The motivation for his putting it on the paper was, I presume, the motivation that I fully understood- his frustration at the failure of his Government to succeed in obtaining references from the States, or at least all the States, under section 51 (xxxvii ) of the Constitution to enable the Commonwealth to legislate in this area and thus to solve the problems both of the substantive law and of jurisdiction. As to possible explanations, I suppose one would have to ask him why that occurred. Two explanations suggest themselves. One is that on further reflection--
—Is this in your ministerial portfolio?

—One explanation of which I am aware is that it could be argued that the proposal was deserving of further consideration on its merits. In particular, an argument was put on the floor of the Convention that, insofar as the matter referred to rights and liabilities in relation to property, it could result in the Commonwealth intruding unnecessarily into the State domain further than the demands of the subject matter properly justified. As to that, I said on the Convention floor that I gave a very firm undertaking that we would look very carefully at the drafting of that part of the proposal and indeed consult with the States and make any draft available to the States before any such proposal was put to referendum, to ensure that there was no foundation for that concern. The only other explanation that suggests itself to me is the one put directly to me by Senator Durack when I asked him on the floor of the Convention: 'Why on earth are you opposing this particular matter which was, after all, your resolution?' The reply was-and it is a very revealing one-'Well, we are not in government now, are we'.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Industry and Commerce. By way of brief introduction I refer to the Government's undertaking to ' strengthen our anti-dumping procedures and provide for speedy reviews by the Temporary Assistance Authority'. Can the Minister advise the Senate what measures have been taken to achieve these goals and what steps the Government now proposes to take? How effective have the steps been in reducing the time taken to deal with dumping allegations and inquiries? In particular, can the Minister advise when a decision can be expected from the Government on the Korean passenger vehicle tyre imports question, the formal investigations for which have been completed now for more than a month?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has asked about the review of dumping procedures which is taking place within the Department. First of all, it is the intention of the Government that as far as possible procedures for dealing with dumping complaints should be speeded up. The review is largely directed towards that question as well as to other questions dealing with such matters as the onus of proof in dumping complaints and so on. The Department has now virtually completed that review and, as is the Government's announced intention, will be consulting with various interested parties in industry in the latter half of this month. It is the Government's intention that that consultative process should take place, and I have already had discussions with representatives of a number of companies interested in dumping matters. Accordingly, it is not appropriate at this stage to answer that part of the question which seeks to establish how effective the steps taken have been.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been a continual concern about this matter for up to two years now. The previous Government, I think, took some steps to see that the procedures were speeded up and this Government has taken further steps. It is impossible to answer the question as to how effective the steps have been, except to say that it is the belief of my Department that the time taken in dealing with dumping complaints will be substantially reduced by the middle of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Korean ones?
—That matter is currently before the Department. I am not in a position to give a definitive answer at this stage.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. It refers to the statement made at the recent Housing Summit Conference by the President of the Real Estate Institute of Australia, Mr Malcolm Gray, that the Federal Government scheme to assist home buyers should be means tested to ensure that benefits are directed only to those needing them. Can the Minister say whether the Government is presently assessing this particular housing situation as part of the overall priority of assisting the truly needy during the current restraints?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not present when Mr Gray made that statement. I thank Senator Elstob for drawing my attention to it. Over recent years, as honourable senators would know, access to home ownership in this country has declined. Significantly higher interest rates and higher house prices have excluded many low income earners from home ownership. This was directly as a result of the previous Government's policies. It is the aim of this Government to encourage home ownership for as many people in the community as possible. In doing this, priority is being given to the development of more effective forms of assistance so that low and moderate income earners can purchase their own homes.

ANSWER.PARA: The first new initiative is the home ownership assistance scheme, which will allow prospective first home buyers to borrow up to $14,000 more from lending institutions to bridge the deposit gap. This will have the effect of increasing the demand for new dwellings and increasing activity in the building industry, and therefore increasing employment which has a further effect of assisting low income earners. The Government is aware of the need to increase the supply of funds for housing and is giving high priority to increasing the availability of housing finance at affordable rates and also to increasing the stock of public housing, both of which will assist at this level of the market. To obtain exact and final details for both Senator Elstob and the Senate I will refer the question to the Minister for Housing and Construction.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is it a fact that he acquiesced in the briefing of senior counsel in an appeal before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to resist an application under the Freedom of Information Act by one Jack Waterford regarding access to prior documents under the existing Act? Did the Queen's Counsel submit a case in the appeal which is diametrically opposed to the policy of the Government in respect of access to prior documents? If so, does this mean that Government policy on this matter has changed or does it simply mean that the Government lost control over the Secretary to the Treasury in regard to the presentation of the defence in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that senior counsel was briefed in the particular Administrative Appeals Tribunal matter to which the honourable senator refers. That brief predated the present Government. In fact, it occurred during Senator Durack's own tenure. Since the brief had been given and the matter had been set down for hearing and determination on a particular date shortly after the Australian Labor Party assumed office, I did not think it was fair to either side to try to countermand that. It is a matter for the Department to decide whom it briefs in these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: The general policy of the administration of the Freedom of Information Act is, of course, as the Senate would well know, one for the Attorney-General. I have been endeavouring to ensure that there is some consistency and uniformity of approach as between departments in the way in which they administer the Act and, in particular, the nature of the arguments they advance to the Tribunal. There was some discussion involving me prior to that matter coming on for hearing. I made very clear my view that a particular approach to the construction of the provision in question ought to be argued. In the event, I understand, a two-tier argument was put, more or less in the alternative-a narrow view and a rather broader view. I do not regard that as being entirely satisfactory and it certainly did not accord with my view as to how the matter should have been pursued. I simply regard these matters as teething problems, early days in the administration of the legislation, and not indicative of any of the horrors to which the former Attorney-General draws our attention. I cannot forbear from making the point that, were he so concerned with the effective and vigorous application and administration of the freedom of information legislation, one would have wished for rather more far-ranging content in that legislation and some signs of a more vigorous application of it in practice during his tenure of office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I am concerned to know what is the Government's policy at the moment in relation to this matter and to what extent the Attorney-General, as the first law officer, controls the arguments that are put to tribunals in respect of the legal implementation of government policy. That is why I asked the Attorney-General: Has the policy changed as a result of the submission that was put? Does he not agree that, as Attorney-General, he should be directing counsel to submit arguments which are in accordance with Government policy?

—If the former Attorney-General wants me to spell it out in any more detail, I will do so. The Government proposes a broader interpretation of section 12 (2) (b) of the Act than was current during his tenure. We are perfectly pleased and proud to adopt that point of view as it is, in our belief, far more consistent with the proper tenor of interpretation of the Act. I made that clear in the instructions that were sent down through and across the system . It is my belief that that argument was in fact put. It seems that, in the event, it was not put quite as vigorously as I might have hoped in the circumstance. I am taking further steps to ensure that when these matters are raised, dealt with and argued in the future, arguments about basic questions of policy and interpretation of the Act are put in a way that is single-mindedly consistent with the Government's interpretation of that Act.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator McINTOSH

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Leader of the Government in the Senate will be aware, the Governor-General's Speech at the opening of Parliament on 21 April stated:

INTERJECT.PARA: Parliament will be asked to consider a proposal for a 'Buy Australian' Act.

Therefore, I ask: First, when is it intended that such legislation will be introduced; secondly, will any quality control mechanisms be set up; and, thirdly, is there any intention on the part of the Government to try to have State governments enact similar legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator is correct. The Government gave an undertaking prior to the election that it would introduce 'buy Australian' legislation. It is the hope of the Government that that legislation will be introduced in the Budget session this year. Insofar as the question relates to quality control mechanisms set up for purchases, I am sure that that would be part of any intelligent 'buy Australian' Act. If it were not the intention of the Government to ensure that that is so, Senator McIntosh's question would stimulate us to consider that matter in considerable detail. I am asked also whether the Government has any intention of trying to have State governments enact similar legislation. At the moment I believe the answer to be no, but the Government has already had discussions with State governments regarding their purchasing policies and preferences. It is to be hoped that as a result of those discussions the parochialism which has characterised purchasing policies of State governments for some years will disappear.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Does the Government intend to authorise an ex-gratia payment to cover the expenses incurred by the parents of Kenneth Dax due to the unusual and special circumstances of his death following a leakage of gas aboard HMAS Tobruk? Does the Government also intend to make available to Mr and Mrs Dax all documents concerning the death of their son, provided defence secrets are not included? If so, will the Minister explain when the Government plans to take these actions?

—I am aware of the case to which the honourable senator referred. I understand that the Minister for Defence, Mr Scholes, took a personal interest in this case for some time while he was shadow Minister. He undertook to pursue the matter in government and, I understand, has now requested a full report on the case. I further understand that this report is virtually completed. I will communicate the honourable senator's concern to the Minister for Defence and ask him to ensure that the case is dealt with as soon as practicable and, when it is dealt with, that all matters that can reasonably be made public are made public so that the fears and concerns of the honourable senator can be put to rest.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. The Minister will be aware that the Darwin office of the Australian Information Service was closed by the former Government in its so-called efficiency drive. The closing of the office was keenly felt by both the Service and the people of the Northern Territory. Will the Minister undertake to consider the reopening of the office, possibly by the reallocation of resources from one of the other capital city offices of the Service, and so provide the Northern Territory with a most needed facility?

—Senator Robertson has asked me a question dealing with the Australian Information Service which comes under the responsibility of my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services. The Minister has advised me on a number of matters. He is retracing steps in respect of a whole range of decisions made by the previous Government to which the Australian Labor Party objected. I have not been kept aware of the Minister's attitude on this matter. I certainly will draw it to his attention and see that the honourable senator is given an early answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware of a second flight by a Royal Australian Air Force F111 aircraft over South West Tasmania on 24 March 1983? Did this aircraft seek to gather evidence for the Commonwealth in relation to the pending High Court of Australia litigation over the Gordon below Franklin Dam?
—No, I am not aware of any such flight.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security whether he has any estimate of the need for emergency relief in the community. What information is available about the kinds of people who need crisis help? Finally, what does the Government see as its priorities in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The assessment of need for emergency relief has worried not only me but also the previous Minister for Social Security. Some two years ago, I believe, a combined report on emergency relief was prepared by the Australian Council of Social Service and the Department of Social Security which estimated that the need may be as high as $14m per year. Until the end of last year the Federal appropriation for emergency relief was $0.5m. At the end of last year the Government, realising the very difficult situation which had arisen because of the rapidly deteriorating economic situation, provided another $2m. This amount goes nowhere near meeting the need for emergency relief. A working party of welfare administrators recently did a survey of these needs in Australia and it was discovered, for instance, that in New South Wales alone the Government provides some $260,000 per week in cash grants. If we add to that the $250,000 per week allocated for rent relief it can be seen that the need is considerable.

ANSWER.PARA: It is disturbing to find from the surveys that have been done on this subject that those who are most in need of emergency relief are, in fact, usually social security recipients. In the surveys done in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia the figure for social security recipients varied between 70 per cent and 80 per cent. The four main groups were lone parents in receipt of Department of Social Security pensions or benefits, usually being the supporting parent's benefit, who do not own their own homes-in other words, they are in private rental accommodation; couples with children and lone adults in receipt of unemployment, sickness and special benefits who, again, do not own their own homes; invalid pensioners; and those awaiting the first payment of a social security pension or benefit.

It is quite clear that high inflation, high unemployment, rapidly increasing costs in the community and the deteriorating state of the economy in recent years have greatly increased the need for emergency relief. This has resulted in normally conservative organisations such as the Salvation Army in Victoria going public and making very stringent political comments about the inadequacy of the economic system and the inadequacy of the social security system in coping with those in need. We, as a government, see emergency relief as a necessary evil at the moment because it is a band-aid sort of solution to people's very difficult situations. It is even more disturbing to find, as all surveys have shown, that whereas emergency relief was once a one-off thing people are more and more having to go back again and again for emergency relief. We would prefer that the need for emergency relief be nil or very little. That will not occur, I suppose, until the unemployment rate in particular goes down and the economy improves. In the meantime, on 17 June I will be meeting the State Ministers for social security, community welfare, or whatever they are called in the various States, to consider the distribution of emergency relief and the amount of emergency relief which will be needed. In the meantime my Department and other departments are conducting surveys to find out the actual quantum of that need.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: In view of the Hawke Government's strong advocacy of fixed term parliaments and its vehement criticism of any government running less than its full term, will his Government give an unqualified assurance that it will run its full term until March 1986 and not seek an earlier polling date, whether to bring the Senate and House of Representatives elections in parallel or for any other purpose?

—It is the Government's intention to introduce a referendum in relation to fixed term parliaments-a course of action which was vociferously opposed for three years by Senator Sir John Carrick in the Senate. I am delighted by his new-found principles which have emerged in Opposition. The Government will not give Senator Sir John Carrick an unqualified assurance about anything until it has made up its mind about the things for which assurances are being sought. When the Government has made up its mind about those matters assurances will be given and they will be stuck to. Insofar as the question of fixed term parliaments is concerned, this Government will put its money where its mouth is and has been for a number of years, which is something that no Liberal government was prepared to do.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs . Is the Minister aware of representations made by the National Women's Advisory Council regarding the eligibility of World War II ex-servicewomen in regard to defence service home loans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the arrangements now stand, of course, only those ex- servicewomen who served overseas during World War II are eligible for defence service home loans. However, the Government has indicated very clearly that it is moving in every direction to remove any form of discrimination so far as women are concerned. Consequently, we are looking very seriously at this question of the number of women who served during World War II and their eligibility for defence service home loans. I might add that the previous Government did receive a request, which I understand was unanimous, from the National Women's Advisory Council. It pointed out that women who are not eligible unless they have served overseas include members of the Citizen Military Forces, the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service and the Voluntary Aid Detachment. The exclusion of these groups was a matter of long-standing practice based on ministerial directive. It was not until 1978 that the relevant Act was amended to incorporate these exclusions by law.

ANSWER.PARA: The Council says that those exclusions are discriminatory and the Government agrees with that.
