NATIONAL ECONOMIC SUMMIT CONFERENCE
Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a statement on the National Economic Summit Conference.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
I wish to make a full report to the House on the National Economic Summit Conference, as foreshadowed by the Treasurer on 21 April when he tabled documents which had been submitted to the Conference.

The National Economic Summit Conference which assembled in this place on 11 April, 1983 was, by any standards, a significant and historic event. No such conference of this scale or scope had been attempted before in Australia. It represented a new beginning, a first step towards our great national goals of national reconciliation, national reconstuction and national recovery. It is now possible to reflect thoughtfully on the outcome of the Conference, to identify its key elements and to translate them into an action plan for all of us to follow in working towards recovery. Indeed in the two and a half weeks since its conclusion, important steps have already been taken by the Government and principal participants to ensure that the work of the Conference becomes the basis for continuing and effective processes in the task of national recovery.

The Government has already tabled in this House the Government documents submitted to the Conference and Volume 2-a transcript of Conference proceedings- out of a planned three-volume record of Conference documents and proceedings.

Volume 1 of this record-a consolidated set of the Government papers already tabled in the House-and Volume 3-containing submissions to the Conference by other participants and observers-are not yet available but will be tabled shortly. I regret the delay in the availability of the third volume particularly , but would observe that perhaps only the most diligent parliamentarians would be now have fully absorbed the documents tabled already.

I would like to thank, at the outset, both your predecessor as Speaker of the House of Representatives, Sir Billy Snedden, and the former President of the Senate, Sir Harold Young, for their ready agreement to make Parliament House and its services available for the Summit Conference. I would also like to thank Members of Parliament for their co-operation in assisting delegates to the Conference with office and other facilities, and for their forbearance in suffering any inconvenience caused.

I turn now to the main business of this Statement. We called the Summit Conference because Australia is facing its gravest economic and social crisis in 50 years. In the words of the Summit Communique:

'The Australian economy is in deep recession. Economic activity and employment are continuing to fall and unemployment is still rising. Profits are depressed, and wage earners have had to accept deferral of improvements and maintenance of living standards. Inflation and interest rates remain high. There are signs of improvement in the world economy and of an end to the drought in the eastern States. There is wide agreement, however, that sustained economic recovery and significant inroads into the unacceptably high level of unemployment will require a steady improvement in business and consumer confidence and more effective processes of income determination. There is also wide recognition that Australia's economic problems are deep-seated and not amenable to rapid solution .'
The call for a National Economic Summit Conference came from many sections of the community and most importantly, had the clear endorsement of the Australian people at the 1983 Federal election.

The Conference has been a long time in its genesis. Well before the recent election campaign, I had advocated such a meeting. I would remind the House that , even before the election was called, I had this to say on 30 January 1983:

'We will convene a National Summit Conference with representatives from the employers, the ACTU and the State Governments . . . to expose all of us together , to the realities of what is happening in the domestic and international economic scene and the problems, dangers, opportunities and challenges of what is involved in those developments.'
At that stage, the envisaged purpose was to

'. . . attempt to analyse the reciprocal implications of movements in wages, profits, patterns of work and individual reconstruction. This Conference [as I said then] would clearly occupy several days and provision would be made for an early follow-up if the parties considered it desirable. . . .'

The concept and procedures I outlined at that time, and in more detail in the course of the recent election campaign, were faithfully followed in arrangements for the Conference. The Government made every effort to ensure that those invited were as fully representative as possible of Australian industry, the Australian workforce and the Australian people through their elected governments . The letters of invitation were sent immediately the Government was formally sworn in, on 11 March 1983.

The 100 participants who accepted my invitation included representatives of all State Governments and of the local government sector. The union movement was represented by the full ACTU Executive. Business was represented through two avenues: through the representative business organisations the whole structure of business, large and small, was covered; and in addition, many individual businessmen from some of the largest individual enterprises were invited.
The Australian Council of Social Services was invited as the major umbrella organisation in the social welfare sector.
In addition the Government recognised that community organisations had a valid role to play in the process and 18 such organisations were invited to send observers.

Understandably perhaps, some fears were raised that the Conference could not succeed and that it might simply become a forum for partisan position-taking and disputation. There were some perhaps, who thought that the spirit of conflict and confrontation has become irrevocably entrenched in this country. But the Conference was never envisaged in any way as a point-scoring exercise, let alone a partisan political affair, nor did it turn out to be. That it did not is a high tribute indeed to the responsibility shown by all participants. In seeking consensus on Australia's economic and social problems from the Conference, the participants were not intent on simply settling for the lowest common denominator, the bare minimum of agreement on an approach to a solution to the current crises. Throughout, the proceedings were marked by a combination of responsibility and realism, practical commonsense, and a sense of our common interests. All participants agreed that every section of the community, excepting only the impoverished, should share the burden of restraint. Further evidence of the constructive spirit in which the Conference was approached by all can be found in the proceedings and in the many worthwhile results that emerged, particularly through the Summit Comminique.

I must stress that never at any stage did we of the Government regard the Conference and its outcome as some means of shirking, or shedding the responsibilities of governments, and particularly the national government, to take decisions. We recognise and re-affirm that we, as the elected representatives of the people of Australia, have the primary and fundamental responsibility for the economic and social policies of this nation. But as I said in my closing address to the Conference, effective policy cannot be made in a vacuum. The Conference made a very substantial contribution to filling that vacuum, to bringing out clearly the economic and social realities which must form the context for Government decisions. We are now all better equipped, and all have a clearer perception of the prospects, possibilities and plain hard work that lies ahead.

In the deepest sense, the Conference was a key step in bringing Australia together. I deeply believe-and I am now doubly reassured that the overwhelming majority of the Australian people believe this also-that Australia can no longer afford to go down the path of confrontation which characterised much of the past decade. What we sought was genuine consensus on the path forward towards national reconciliation, recovery and reconstruction, and the co-operation of all in setting the nation upon that forward path.
Specifically, we set the following objectives for the Conference. They were:

to secure broad agreement on the role of an incomes and prices policy, in our efforts to promote employment and to achieve recovery and growth; and to ensure that the benefits of recovery are not lost in another round of the wages-prices spiral;
to devise machinery for achieving the necessary restraint, including methods of wage fixation, influencing non-wage incomes, and price surveillance;
to secure a better and wider understanding of the broad economic framework, within which we have to operate;

to seek broad agreement on the relationship between a successful prices and incomes policy and the implementation of policies on industrial relations, job creation and training, taxation, social security, health, education and the other major community services;
to examine the competitiveness and efficiency of the Australian economy;

and finally, to reach agreement on arrangements and machinery to monitor and continue the work of this Conference, especially in regard to continuing the process of consultation and co-operation between government, business and unions , initiated by this Conference itself.

The objectives and the problems addressed by the Conference are encapsulated in the question of unemployment and the restoration of sustained economic growth which avoids a new bout of destructive inflation.

As Honourable Members all know, the Conference ran from Monday 11 April to Thursday 14 April. It was well reported in the media, giving many in the community the opportunity to read, view or listen in, and to discuss amongst themselves the important issues raised here.

The sharing and acquiring of knowledge and information which was an essential feature of the Conference itself was extended, in a very real sense, to the community at large. This process of information-sharing is one to which my Government is committed in the future.

Overall, perhaps the most satisfying feature of the Conference from the Government's point of view was the outstanding spirit of co-operation, frankness and willingness to respect the integrity of differing points of view that prevailed throughout. In particular, there was a willingness on the part of all participants to acknowledge that we all bear some responsibility for our current economic malaise and that all have a part to play in overcoming our current difficulties. I believe this augurs well for the implementation of a successful and effective prices and incomes policy, which is a cornerstone for our strategy for economic recovery.
I turn now to the more specific achievements of the Conference. At the broad level, I think there were three of about equal importance:

Firstly the degree of common understanding reached on the nature and source of Australia's economic problems-an achievement due in no small measure to the frank and detailed information and analysis put before the Conference by the Government and by many of the participants and observers themselves;

Secondly, the degree of consensus reached-as expressed in the Communique-on the basic framework and approach required to begin to arrest the decline in our economy, to arrest the expansion in unemployment levels, and, in an ongoing sense, to put our economy on a path of sustained non-inflationary growth; and

Thirdly, the recognition on all sides that the consensus reached at the Conference is only the first step and commitments have been given, again on all sides, to translate that consensus into effective action.

The main specific conclusions of the Summit are set out in the Communique which was tabled earlier in the House along with other documents submitted to or emerging from the Summit Conference. The Communique was virtually unanimously adopted; only the Government of Queensland, from the multitude of participants, formally reserved its position, though even the Queensland Premier by no means rejected entirely its main thrust and conclusions. Naturally not every conclusion and every piece of information shared in the Conference could find expression in such a document. What it had to cover was the principal message of the Summit, the main points of the framework within which we must all now follow up in setting about tackling the serious economic problems facing this country.

I would like now to point out to Honourable Members some of the more significant points made in the Communique. I will necessarily be selective, but would commend the document as a whole for close study by every Member of the parliament and indeed by every Australian who is interested in this nation's welfare.
The key elements of the Communique, as I see them, are:

First, in paragraphs 2 to 5, recognition of the nature and sources of the serious economic problems facing the Australian economy, the need for a co- operative and innovative response to those problems, and, particularly, the recognition that to achieve recovery will require restraint in expectations and claims from all sections of the community except the impoverished;

Second, in paragraph 12, recognition of the importance of tackling the problems of unemployment and inflation simultaneously, and that an effective incomes and prices policy is essential if an expansionary fiscal policy is to be pursued without adverse consequences for inflation;
Third, in paragraph 18, recognition by the trade union movement that the maintenance of real wages will be an objective over time, during a period of economic crisis;

Fourth, in paragraph 20, consensus on a return to a centralised approach to wage fixation and recognition that a suppression of sectional claims is essential except in special or extraordinary circumstances;

Fifth, in paragraph 26, recognition that the Government has a mandate to establish a price surveillance mechanism and agreement on an examination into the most appropriate form of functioning of this mechanism;
Sixth, in paragraphs 24 to 28, agreement that if restraint is to be exercised then such restraint should be exercised universally, including in respect of dividends and non-wage incomes;
Seventh, in paragraph 31, acknowledgement that increased aggregate public expenditure may require increases in taxation or less than full tax indexation;
Eighth, in paragraph 33, recognition that priority in the social security area should be on real improvement in entitlements to those in genuine need;

Ninth, in paragraph 34 acknowledgement that, in the next session of Parliament, the Government would introduce a bill abolishing the Industrial Relations Bureau and facilitating the amalgamation of unions;

Tenth, in parapraphs 43 and 44, agreement that the basic rights of women should be recognised and protected and on the need for imaginative policies to assist young people severely affected by the recession;

Eleventh, in paragraph 48, recognition of the importance of stable health policies and reaffirmation by unions that they will accept an offset in wage increases on account of the introduction of the Government's proposed health insurance scheme;
Twelth, in paragraphs 50 and 52 stress on the importance of continuing the sharing of information to aid understanding of Australia's economic problems;

Thirteenth, in paragraph 53, general agreement that a small independent representative Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) should be established to continue the process of consultation begun at the Conference; and

Finally, in paragraph 54, expression of hope that the Summit marks the beginning of consensus, not the end, recognition of the enormous amount of work that still remains to be done and commitment to that task.

All in the community have a part to play. For its part the Government has already taken a number of concrete steps to follow up the success of the Summit Conference by setting off firmly on the path to recovery to which the Summit pointed.

The representative working party foreshadowed in the Summit Communique has already met under the chairmanship of my colleague the Treasurer, and has made substantial progress in mapping out the most appropriate form and functioning of the proposed Economic Planning Advisory Council and Prices Surveillance Authority. The Government intends to introduce legislation to establish the Economic Planning Advisory Council in this Parliamentary session. Work towards that has taken precedence over work to establish the Prices Surveillance Authority, but the Government intends to introduce legislation to establish the latter in the Budget session.
The Government is also moving to establish a Tripartite Advisory Committee on the prices and incomes policy.
Central to the conclusions of the Summit was the recognition that the degree of restraint exercised in expectations and claims is absolutely vital to Australia' s prospects of recovery.

As far as wages are concerned, the Government will be participating in the Conference on wage fixation scheduled to be held in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We will base our approach to that Conference on the conclusions of the Summit and on the Prices and Incomes Accord. In that context, I would point out again that all at the Summit agreed that if a centralised system of wage fixing is to work, there must be an abstention from sectional claims except in special and extraordinary circumstances. Let me say that my Government's interpretation of what constitutes such circumstances is the commonsense interpretation and leaves no room for selfish claims from maverick sections of the trade union movement. Participants at the Summit Conference recognised that if restraint in incomes is to be exercised then it should be exercised universally. In that spirit of equitable sharing of the burdens of recovery the Summit also stressed the need for restraint in non-wage incomes such as dividends, professional fees and the like.

I have written to the Chief Executives of larger public companies and through the media have addressed the Boards of all public companies in Australia seeking their co-operation in exercising restraint in dividends and non-wage incomes, such as directors' fees, over which they have an influence. It is important that such incomes do not increase faster than movements in wages.

My colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has also written to major national organisations representing non-wage income earners drawing their attention to the Summit outcome and seeking their support in achieving income restraint in their areas. The Minister will also be writing to the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission drawing attention to the Summit Communique in regard to non-wage incomes, and seeking his support in having fees voluntarily reviewed by Commission members.

There was widespread opinion at the Summit that strong expansion of housing construction from recent depressed levels must be an important part of any general economic recovery. My colleague the Minister for Housing and Construction last Thursday in Sydney chaired a post-Summit meeting of building unions and firms involved in housing finance, construction, trade and materials supply. The Treasurer and the Minister for Finance also participated in the meeting. The Summit and the post-Summit meeting both contributed substantially to the ideas that are being developed within government to ensure that housing construction returns to its proper role in the Australian economy. The details of a new housing policy package will be announced soon.

In this context Members will be aware that there will be a special Statement of Economic Measures later this month, announcing a package of relevant economic fiscal measures. These measures will follow up the Summit and build on the new spirit of confidence already evident in the economy since the Summit. Some major elements of the Government's recovery program will be announed, aiming to get the economy moving and to create jobs.

The Summit was a first step. By itself it has already helped to restore confidence, and in that way helped in getting a recovery underway. But its real contribution over the period ahead will fall far short of what is required unless it is effectively and consistently followed up.
There is a responsibility on every Member of the Parliament, and every member of the community to see that the opportunity opened up by the success of the Summit is not frittered away.

The spirit of shared sacrifice and restraint and the determination to take the steps needed to achieve recovery must be carried into effect in all areas: In wages and industrial relations; in the policies of business throughout the economy; and through the policies of Government. I commend this vital national enterprise to each Honourable Member and the nation we represent.

I believe that the Conference did more than establish the basis for confidence in the recovery of the economy. I believe it helped-as a first step-to restore confidence in ourselves as a people and a nation, confidence that we can talk together and work together, that we can co-operate to seek solutions for our common problems, in the knowledge that what unites us is infinitely more important and enduring than the things that divide us. The revival of that sort of confidence in ourselves is essential if we are to overcome our present grave economic problems. But even beyond these problems, this new spirit of confidence and co-operation, if it can grow and strengthen, can be made an enduring basis for an even better and stronger future for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on the statement on the National Economic Summit Conference which has been put down in this place on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). The statement which we have just received does not take us much further than the point we were at before its receipt. The statement is a fairly self-congratulatory description of the processes which have occurred. It does nothing to explain in more detail to us precisely how the Government intends to achieve the objectives which were summarised for us at the Conference by, I think, the Premier of New South Wales as 'jobs, jobs and more jobs'. The statement is basically descriptive, rather than getting down to the difficult task of determining just what action can be taken to achieve that objective which all of us in this chamber support. I should make it clear that of course the Opposition is as anxious as the Government to see an improvement in the employment situation in Australia and wishes to see the Government succeed in its efforts to create a high level of employment and a lower level of unemployment. That is for the economic, the social and the myriad human reasons which have been the subject of so much public discussion over recent months.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to pick up one point which is evident in some of the presentations of the Government on Economic issues; that is, that a spirit of conflict and confrontation is to be avoided. At page 4 of the typed copy of the statement we have received there is reference to that in the sentence which states:
There were some perhaps, who thought the spirit of conflict and confrontation has become irrevocably entrenched in this country.

It is certainly clear that there is a great spirit of confrontation and conflict in the communique which was the ultimate result of the Summit. But I think it is important to make the point in this chamber, which is the place where the community is entitled to be fully represented by its elected representatives and where it expects the varying views which there are in Australia as to what are appropriate solutions to Australia's problems, that those views should be fully aired in this place and not held back because of some broad desire to have agreement for the sake of agreement. There is no advance for Australia in having an agreement on something which is incorrect or which will be counter-productive . To underline the point that I make, it seems to me that one has to go somewhat beyond the conclusion which the communique came to on wage fixation, which appears as paragraph 19 in these terms:

All parties believe that the principles of wage fixation should be such as to provide wage justice to employees whilst seeking to ensure that wage increases do not give added impetus to inflation or unemployment.

That is a statement of general principle with which it might be easy to agree. But I say with great respect to those who framed the communique that it is a rather anodyne statement which does not really advance us very far down the path when we are trying to determine just what precisely we should do to meet that objective. If one looks at the actual contributions which were made by people who attended the Summit one finds that they put rather blunter propositions which were obviously too difficult to be encompassed in the communique, yet which have to be faced up to by the Government if it is going to tackle successfully the very serious problem of unemployment. I wish very briefly to refer the Senate to the sort of contribution which was made by Mr Leard on the first day, reported at page 49 of the official record of the Conference issued by the Government. That contains a very strong statement of what has to be done if we are to meet the challenge which is ahead of all of us and not just this Government. Mr Leard stated:

I believe the choice before us is quite simple. We either have restraint and equality of sacrifice or we do not. If more jobs are to be created 75 per cent of these will be created in the private sector of the mixed economy of Australia . We therefore have to create the economic conditions and environment in which the business section can create those jobs.
He went on to say, a little later:

Prime Minister, I believe the case for income restraint is overwhelming. I believe that the present wage pause should be extended until the end of 1983. During 1984 incomes at the lower levels should be adjusted to allow for cost of living increases to the extend that the economy can afford at that time.

The whole of that passage bears careful reading, but I will not delay the Senate by further quotation from it. I think it is noteworthy that it is clear that by the third or fourth day of the conference-Mr Leard was further reported at page 184 of the record-notwithstanding the general discussions which had taken place, Mr Leard remained of the same very strong view that if we are to tackle that problem there has to be an extension of the wage pause through to the end of 1983 and a very significant degree of wage restraint thereafter. In the same way , contributors such as Mr Morgan, reported at page 108 of the record, made a very powerful point which again cannot be escaped. He stated:

The mining industry is prepared to support a return to central wage fixation providing it involves understandings of an extension of the pause, absence of Catch-up and continuing restraint to aid recovery. The mining industry does not believe that in the long term it is practicable to institutionalise a central wage fixing mechanism for the purpose of fixing total employment conditions.
The system requires comprehensive review by all parties.

Again, that is a rather stronger statement than anything which appears in the communique. It represents a view from which there is no evidence that someone like Mr Morgan has resiled. Sir Arvi Parbo, another contributor invited by the Government, is reported at pages 177 and 178 of the record of the Conference as making the point that we have the twin goals of reducing unemployment and inflation at the same time. He said:

It is generally accepted that this is a tough task which is only possible through a high level of sustained, non inflationery economic growth. The question then becomes one of how we are to achieve this growth. The economic scenarios presented by the Treasurer on Monday all lead to one conclusion; The longer we can hold down further cost increases, the earlier the recovery and the more jobs that will be available. Conversely, if costs go up, there will be delayed recovery and more unemployment. I have heard no disagreement with these conclusions.

It is quite clear that in the proceedings of the National Economic Summit Conference a great number of contributions made the point that there is a need for a very significant degree of wage restraint; indeed, a degree of wage restraint which goes beyond what is currently predicted by the Government as being likely. I understand that in the House of Representatives today the Prime Minister indicated that he would expect a 3 per cent to 4 per cent increase in a general wage round in the latter part of this year. That sort of view, on the scenarios presented by the Government itself through the Treasurer (Mr Keating), will clearly not lead to a substantial improvement in the unemployment situation in Australia over the term of this Government.

I do not intend to go into this matter in detail in this debate because of course there will soon be other opportunities to do so in this chamber. I just wish to make the point that the participants in the Conference, including the Government itself, through the mouth of its Treasurer and the information put before the Conference, faced up to the fact that it requires a significant degree of wage restraint if we are to do anything about unemployment in this country-a degree of wage restraint which appears to exceed what is considered likely or possible by the Government and which is clearly beyond what is considered concedable by the trade union movement. There is no running away from that. The fact is, as several of the people in the Summit Conference acknowledged, that the result of this Summit will in the end be judged on the basis of whether the employment market and the economy improve. It appears to the Opposition that there is a very real danger that under this sort of anodyne collection of good intentions, important and beneficial as they may be to the framework of debate within which these decisions will be made, there has been to date no taking of the hard decisions which would enable the Government to say that it was really approaching the objectives set out by Premier Wran of creating jobs, jobs and more jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that word 'anodyne' mean?

—Bland would do. A number of other points can be made with respect to this statement. On its face it discloses that the Government did not really meet the objectives which it set for itself when it established this Summit. If we look at the first page of the statement which has been put down we find that the Prime Minister, through the mouth of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, is saying:

SPEECH.PARA: It is now possible to reflect thoughtfully on the outcome of the Conference, to identify its key elements and to translate them into an action plan for all of us to follow in working towards recovery.

In other words, all that the Prime Minister is saying is that we have now identified some key elements and we are now in a position to translate them into an action plan. In other words, no action plan has yet been devised by the Government, let alone by the Summit itself. Yet on 11 April, when the Treasurer was addressing the Summit on behalf of the Government, he said:
If this Summit is to succeed it will need to do more than put forward proposals that sound like programs for action but are really only statements of goals-not methods for attaining them.

It is quite clear that on day one of the Conference the Treasurer put forward the view that what was to be produced by the Conference was a program for action . It is quite clear that all we have is an identification of key elements which need to be tackled if a program of action is to be devised. That of course, may be something of value, but I think it is important not to overstate what has been achieved. If we look at paragraph 55 of the communique in particular, we find that the Prime Minister expressed one of the objectives of the Conference as follows:
To devise machinery for achieving the necessary restraint, including methods of wage fixation, influencing non-wage incomes, and price surveillance.

With respect to that key question of finding methods of wage fixation, the fact is that all that the communique does, and all that the Summit has done, is to send that vital area back to the existing method of wage fixation, namely, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. As was evident to in Question Time this morning, when Senator Button made it quite clear that he was not in a position to tell us what the submissions before the Arbitration Commission would be-I think he said they were still being worked on-we have a situation in which the Government has not even identified what line it will take if it is to go before the Commission and urge a course of action which will reduce unemployment. We find that we are left with precisely the same machinery as the previous Government had identified as its means of moving out of the wage freeze, when that moving out occurred namely, that it would proceed through the Arbitration Commission. We have a total failure to live up to the desirable objective of devising the machinery for achieving necessary restraint. All that we have at the moment is a recourse to the traditional tools which are available and a government which is searching around for the submission that it will make to that Commission when the time comes. The Prime Minister fairly confidently predicts wage rises which, on the face of the record of the National Economic Summit, will ensure that there is no substantial growth in employment and certainly no reduction in unemployment over the coming period.

The final point that I wish to deal with at this stage is the fact that the Prime Minister in this statement has pointedly omitted reference to some of the important paragraphs of the National Economic Summit Conference communique, which expressed as the views of business some of the key matters which were stressed by delegates to the Conference. I refer the Senate to paragraphs 15 and 16 of the communique. Paragraph 15 states:

Business participants have emphasised their concern with overall unit costs of production and their importance in preserving the competitiveness of business and therefore its ability to survive, expand and create jobs.
Paragraph 16 continues:
They-
That means the business participants--

maintain that to achieve the growth in GDP and employment on which the nation's prosperity will depend, increased profitability is now essential if new investment is to be generated at an effective level.

I do not think there are two more critically important paragraphs in the communique. It is an unfortunate fact that on the face of the communique they are expressed as the views of the business participants only although, from the views which I have quoted in part today, it is quite clear that they are certainly the strongly held views of the business participants at the Summit. In looking at the submission which the Treasurer made to the Summit, I think the Government should have been ready to agree with those paragraphs as being the views of government also and to urge before the Commission that that was a common view which should be taken into account very carefully before any further rises in wages were granted. In other words, I would have wished to see on the face of the communique an embracing by both the trade union movement and the Government of the sorts of principles which Mr Leard tried to put down and which he expressed in his two contributions. They reflected some of the views which Senator Button put in a rather tentative way in response to my question this morning when he made the point that one could possibly draw a distinction between high and low income earners and make various other adjustments to take into account the very complicated factors which apply in this area.

The statement which has been put before us again takes us little further along the track except to assure us that there is a better public understanding of the issues. I would accept that that is the case. I think one of the great successes of the Summit has been to ensure that there is a much broader public appreciation of the issues which face the Government and the community if we are to solve the very serious problem of unemployment. I would acknowledge as a very positive step the release of information which has not previously been made available to assist the public debate in this area. Having said that, it seems to me that at the moment the Government is proving strong on rhetoric and short on prescription. The real test of the Government will be when it gets down to the problem of prescribing the actual policies which will be followed by it if it is to achieve the laudable objectives it set for itself and for Australia.

There was, of course, great public expectation that the Summit would produce a great deal. I believe there is growing public perception that the Summit has produced understanding of problems rather than solutions. I point out that last year the previous Government achieved a major element of consensus between the governments of Australia which made common approaches to the industrial tribunals around the country seeking a wage pause. It is quite clear that the government and most, if not all, of the participants at the Conference now accept the wisdom of the wage pause which was instituted basically after great and sometimes acrimonious discussion on a consensual basis between governments. We have now seen that consensus reduced rather than increased by the events of the last few months and, of course, we have had the very worrying spectre of some of the trade union statements on wage possibilities and demands for increased wages over recent weeks.

I believe that very significant questions are yet to be determined. I will await with very great interest what submissions the Government finally makes to the arbitration authorities with respect to the pause. What stance will the Government take on matters such as a catch-up, the extension of the pause and the principles which are to be applied in determining whether further wage rises will further reduce employment and thereby increase hardship in our community? These are all matters on which the hard decisions are yet to be taken. They are central to the problems in this area and I believe that we are a long way short yet of finding the Government putting forward solutions which do have the support of all sections of the community and which will work for the community and, in particular, for the unemployed. I understand that there will be further opportunities to debate this and related matters later in the week. I therefore, at this stage, seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-May I, at the outset, in these few brief remarks-like the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, I hope to have an opportunity to participate in the fuller debate-compliment Senator Chaney on what I believe was a most responsible and critically constructive speech. It was so different from what we used to hear in this place that I believe Senator Chaney is to be commended for the new spirit he is bringing into the debates in this place by giving credit where it is due and, when he is being critical, being constructive in that criticism. I compliment him for that. I also join with those people who want to congratulate the Hawke Government for the concept of the National Economic Summit Conference. I believe it was a tremendous success not only in political terms but also in social and economic terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The Summit Conference was an arrangement that is totally in keeping with Australian Democrat philosophy. In fact, it is a proposition I outlined in some detail in a book I wrote in 1977. It is a concept that is enshrined in Australian Democrat policy and philosophy. Without making too fine a point of it , I ask the Australian Labor Party, if it is going to use slogans again, whether it at least might drop me an 'in confidence' note saying it is stealing our slogan because in 1977 the Australian Democrats, by national vote, coined as the national slogan for our party: 'Get Australia together'. But I am told that imitation is the finest form of flattery and I thank the Labor Party for its compliment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It still cost us a packet. We might get some of our money back.

—It did not do you any harm; that is obvious. The only sour note I want to strike-I do not make a fine point of this-is that it seemed to be a contradiction in terms to have Mr Hawke say 'Let us have consultation and not confrontation; let us have an exchange of information philosophy' and then, quite commendably, for him to invite 100 or so leading people in various fields, endeavours and disciplines in Australia to the conference but not to invite representatives of all other political parties. That seemed to me to be a rather quaint way of trying to reach a consensus. The nation probably is facing the worst economic problems it has ever had and we have proposals from a conference which clearly-as Senator Chaney said, we will need more than rhetoric to get us out of this problem-will need legislation to be passed through this Parliament at some time. I would have thought not only that is was proper but also that it was politically wise to invite representatives of other political parties to the Summit, even as observers. As observers they would not have been permitted to get into the Conference and grandstand. In some way the other political parties in Australia should have been locked into the spirit of the Summit, the spirit of consultation. I just say that I believe it was a mistake and it was unfortunate that they were not invited, but we should not let that criticism outweigh the praise and the congratulations I have for the Government on its concept.

SPEECH.PARA: I do hope that this Summit idea will continue. I hope that this will not be a once-off affair. I also hope that the concept changes to some extent to that which I outlined in my book in 1977 and that which I understand was outlined by Mr Hawke in the Boyer lectures he delivered in 1977-78 on which we had long personal discussions at that time. As I understood the concept, it did not involve a conference in a grand Parliament House, the proceedings of which were televised, with people making prepared speeches. The concept was to involve several meetings of smaller groups in camera so that a spirit of compromise-give and take-could be tried. I thought that the conference should be ongoing and not just a big event once a year or once every two years. But the first Conference has been held and it has been successful. I wish the Government well in its initiative and hope that it will change the concept along the lines I have mentioned.

The Australian Democrats and I see the first achievement of the Summit as being a recognition and an acceptance by the employers of the need for a centralised wage fixation system, and the second as being an acceptance by the unions of the need for wage moderation and for future wage rises to be linked in some way to productivity. We talk for hours in this place but what a magnificent achievement that was.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but they are not doing it, are they?

—Some of them are not doing it. I would have thought that it was an incredible achievement to have trade unionists agreeing, even before the Summit began, that in the last two years increases in real wages had outstripped increases in productivity and then saying that that is a recipe for disaster. I do not know whether that is happening but I think it is a most valuable advance at least to have got that on the record and to have a recognition by responsible trade union leaders such as Cliff Dolan that that is a fact.

SPEECH.PARA: The third achievement was the widespread disclosure of what was formerly confidential information. We now have price surveillance of a kind. Who knows whether it will work better than the Liberal Party's Prices Justification Tribunal. I do not know, but at least it is an honest attempt along that line. Agreement seems to have been reached to extend the wages pause to non-wage and salary incomes. That is valuable. There is limited, if any, catch-up at the end of the wages pause.

While the Summit did break the climate of confrontation and establish some points of agreement, a dispassionate analysis will show that it did not-it was not intended to-address the fundamental economic choices that this country must make. As my colleague Senator Haines stated today, the Summit which was really a statement of goals was very valuable but it was not a recitation of methods of achieving those goals. To have done that at such a conference would have been a miracle and nobody expected it to be done. Let us not get carried away and say that the Summit, although it was a success, provides the panacea per se of our economic problems. The danger in the Summit being such a public relations success-I warn the Government, with respect, about this-is that some people may come to see it as providing the Government with an alternative mandate. The Australian Democrats do not see that as being the case. The mandate of the Summit is not superior to the mandate of the voters and the mandate of the Parliament.

The Summit concluded that unemployment and inflation must be attacked simultaneously. We do not believe that. We believe that employment must be given the greatest priority-the highest priority. Figures now show that 823,000 people are registered as unemployed. The number could get higher. Solving unemployment does not only mean giving those people a job. In the next two or three years two million more people will be coming into the work force. That means we need to find or create nearly three million jobs in the next two or three years. That is the magnitude of the problem. The Government has the sympathy of the Australian Democrats and will get every co-operation from us in tackling that mammoth task of creating or finding jobs for something like three million people over the next two or three years. Unless we change our economic base radically we could have a permanent pool in Australia of one million unemployed Australians.

I will not bore the Senate to any degree again with my plea to the Government to look to the long-term structures in our employment system that are causing problems. I refer to automation, the technological revolution, the robot and the silicon chip. These things are having permanent effects on human beings in Australia. The last Government did not address itself to these problems and, I am sorry to say, this Government is also not prepared to address itself to them. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), is the only Minister in the Cabinet and the only politician in this country apart from myself, who is being tedious enough to say in every speech that he delivers that the technolgical revolution is the biggest problem facing Australia. Lord Hirshfield predicts that by 1990 there will be something like 50 per cent unemployment in Australia caused by the technological revolution. Lord Hirshfield said that all the goods and services being produced-he said this in 1981-would, by 1990, be produced by only 10 per cent of the existing work force. If we maintain our present hours of work, our present penalty rates and our present attitudes towards job sharing, part time work and definitions of work, what the hell does that mean if it does not mean that 90 per cent of jobs existing today simply will not be there in 10 years' time?

I have mentioned that neither the previous Government nor this Government has addressed itself to this question. Again, that is a statement. It is not necessarily a harsh criticism of the Fraser Government or of this Government because our whole system is geared for governments to survive over a three-year period. This Government is now looking at holding another election by November 1984. It is staring it in the face. In about six months we will probably be in an election year again. That is not the present Government's fault. It is the fault of not having fixed term parliaments in this country. How can we address ourselves to questions that will hit this country 10 years from now if after six months of activity this Government which has just been elected finds itself in an election year again? The whole thing is just insane. Yet, at the same time secretly, under the surface, a gnawing and an erosion of a social fabric, namely , the availability of jobs for our children is taking place. In conclusion, I again compliment the Government on its Summit. I compliment and congratulate those who took part. I wish the Government well in implementing the policies which arose from the rhetoric that came out of the Summit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-My contribution will be in the nature of a preliminary comment, of course, because there will be an opportunity for the Senate to debate this paper at more length later. I simply want to take up a couple of matters the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, has raised. I am not one of those whose nose was out of joint for not being invited to the National Economic Summit Conference. I believe that the Government acted properly in not inviting any member of the Opposition, the Australian Democrats or myself to that gathering. To do so would have been in a way to have suborned the functions of parliamentarians and Parliament itself. Frankly, we do have an expressive as well as an audit control function. We should not exercise those functions in the arena of a national economic summit and should not attend such a conference on the same basis as union and business leaders. We should exercise those functions in the Parliament itself. That is the proper place for us to exercise our audit control and expressive and representative functions.

SPEECH.PARA: The functions and responsibilities of the Parliament should not become too submerged in the operations of any group of people, including the Economic Summit. By the same token, however, I believe that care should be taken to ensure that the National Economic Summit Conference and its ongoing council-the Economic Planning Advisory Council-do not become the foundation of some sort of corporate state. The combined rule of big government, big business and big unions would spell an end to parliamentary democracy in Australia. This, I believe, was far from the mind of the Government and far from the minds of those persons who were invited to the Summit. In my view they had no intention of usurping the role of the elected Parliament. If they had, then they would have another think coming. The Government also has another think coming if it chooses to use the communique of the Summit inevitably to back down on the carrying out of certain undertakings it has given. By inevitably I mean in the long term. Obviously circumstances do arise from time to time producing considerations as to whether a particular undertaking that has been given should be observed at a particular time.

I believe that the main concern of those who attend the National Economic Summit Conference was to focus national attention on the economic and social problems confronting us and to propose solutions to the Government. I commend to all those who have not read the speeches which were prepared in detail and submitted to the Summit by business and union leaders that they do so because the speeches contain a wealth of information and valuable ideas which could be built upon.

For its part the Government, as evidenced by the speech of the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke), was and is intent on revealing the problem in the stark reality of statistics. However, I agree that the question of automation was not adequately addressed in the paragraphs of the communique. I think Senator Chipp was probably too effusive, on his own behalf and on behalf of the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, in suggesting that they were the only parliamentarians who are addressing this aspect of technological change. I know a number of colleagues in the Parliament are doing this. I ran seminars on this very problem as far back as 1964. Of course it is a matter of grave concern to us. It is a matter of grave concern, quite justifiably, to the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones and I am very pleased that such a person is addressing his mind to it.

In addition to that, no paragraph of the communique mentions a very important aspect, without an understanding of which we cannot come to grips with the problem of unemployment, and that is the participation rate. Unemployment, simply stated, is when there are more people seeking paid work than there are jobs available. At the same time new jobs are being slashed through the haphazard introduction of automation and technological change. Commendable as most of the communique was, it did not address that problem. Today I wish to flag that matter very briefly and to suggest that without an analysis of the current participation rate of persons 15 to 65 years of age we will not be able to attack or address ourselves properly to the unemployment situation.

The position simply is this: Had we today the participation rate that we had in the golden years of full employment-that is, in the 1965 era-we would not have an unemployment problem; we would have an employment problem. On the basis of a 56 per cent participation rate, as was the case in 1965, 100,000 jobs would be not filled. As I said, I simply want to flag that matter now recognising that at a later stage we will be able to have a longer and more adequate debate on the Economic Summit. Overall, I commend the initiative and effort that was put into the Summit by those who participated but I am concerned that two fundamental aspects in the equation did not feature prominently in the communique.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

I think it was a matter of agreement between the various parties-I hope Senator Harradine was consulted about this; there was certainly agreement between the Opposition and the Government-that at the time of the rising of the Senate tonight we would mention some of our former colleagues in the Senate who departed as a result of a precipitate and opportunistic decision that was made in January of this year. When the Senate rose in December last year we did not anticipate that an election would be called in the unusual circumstances in which it was and we did not realise that we would not have the opportunity, in the normal course of events and in their presence, to pay tribute to a number of honourable senators who have now retired from the Senate, whether voluntarily or otherwise. On behalf of the Government I will mention them briefly. I propose to do so in alphabetical order in order that I might appear to display my favours with equity.

First of all I would like to mention Senator Bonner who, from 1971 to 1983, was a member of this chamber. He was the first Aboriginal elected to Federal Parliament and I think he was respected by everybody in the Senate not only for his friendliness and personal qualities but also, if I might say so, for his great personal dignity. In the time I have been a member of the Senate I suppose there have been two honourable senators-I single them out by name-who have managed to keep this chamber silent and very respectful while they were speaking , because of the dignity of their speeches. Senator Bonner was one and my colleague Senator Georges was the other. Senator Georges made such a speech, as I recall, after he had spent a period in gaol in Brisbane. I think that that was one of the memorable speeches of my time here as were several of Senator Bonner. I have no doubt that Senator Bonner will continue to play a leading role in Australian public life. I have seen a statement from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that this Government would like to see that happen and I am sure that would be welcomed by all sides.

Senator Keeffe was a senator from 1954 to 1983. He played a great role in the Australian Labor Party, particularly in north Queensland, being a resident senator at Townsville. He had a wide range of interests and made a consistent contribution to debate in this chamber. Senator Keeffe, whatever party differences people might have had with him from time to time, served this country in the war and afterwards in public life. I think the best summation of Senator Keeffe is that everybody recognised that he was a big, good human being.

Senator McLaren, who was a member of the Senate from 1970 to 1983, was a very prolific contributor of questions and notices of motion and participant in adjournment debates. I have a strange feeling that honourable senators will probably get to bed earlier now than they did in the years in which Senator McLaren was a member of this chamber. His departure has, in a sense, some strange irony about it. When I heard that Senator McLaren was leaving us I wondered who would ask questions about Doug Anthony's interest rate on his house but, in terms of the relevance of those questions, Mr Anthony has left us too.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the mortgage was discharged as well.

—Senator Chaney tells me that the mortgage was discharged as well -too late perhaps. That is a good thing and it is a great tribute to Senator McLaren that it was discharged. Senator McLaren was a very diligent senator who had a most prolific filing system, which included his mind. He had a marvellous collection of facts and material in his head which he used to contribute to debates.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Martyr was here from 1981 to 1983. He served in both Houses and on some committees. I suppose it is a tribute to him that he drove me mad on the two committees that I was on with him; that was again a manifestation of hard work by a senator on a committee.

Senator Mulvihill was a major contributor to debates in this place and a persistent if sometimes angry questioner of Ministers. In areas of his interests he was a most persistent representative of the concerns which he had-concerns about immigration and conservation matters and so on-to the extent that he amused all of us with his degree of knowledge of blue crested wrens, kangaroos and things of that kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —The booby bird.
—That is in Boobialla, is it not! He knew about all those things and many of us did not. Tony Mulvihill is a person of great integrity. I believe that is recognised on all sides of the Senate.
—And a great lover of scab unionists.

—That will be recorded in Hansard, no doubt. I should like to pay a personal tribute to another senator who spent a relatively short time here; that was John Siddons. He was here between 1980 and 1983. He was the first Australian Democrat elected as a second senator for his party in the State of Victoria, or indeed in any State, and he was the first Democrat to suffer electoral defeat. I regarded Senator Siddons as a man of great personal integrity. He pursued a number of issues such as industrial democracy, legislation and so on in this place. It was a breath of fresh air in many ways that he was here. The Democrats have, of course, suffered from his defeat.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Thomas and Senator Sir Harold Young were both Liberal Party senators. One was from Western Australia. The first served as Deputy Government Whip and the second had the distinction of becoming President of the Senate. I should like to say first of all about Senator Thomas that he was well regarded by everyone here, I believe. It is a source of regret that such a relatively young senator should not have returned as a result of that unfortunate decision to which I referred earlier. Senator Sir Harold Young was, I think, regarded by all senators as a very fair and decent President of the Senate. I am sure I speak for everybody when I say that we all regarded him as such and wish him well.

Altogether those senators served 81 years in this place, if we accumulate their service. Their contributions to debates in this chamber and their committee activity will be missed. However, the Senate has some degree of continuity about it and new senators replace them and, I believe, add lustre to the chamber. On behalf of the Government, speaking of them collectively, we wish them all well in their retirement. We hope that it will not be the last occasion on which they have the opportunity to serve this country in public life of one kind or another . We will miss them here and hope that they have a secure and happy future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too, on behalf of senators who sit behind me and on my own behalf, should like to express good wishes to all of those senators who retired due to the recent double dissolution. If I may vary slightly the procedure initiated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) I will refer first to those who served with me in the Senate as members of the Liberal Party of Australia. Otherwise, I will follow his precedent by dealing with them in alphabetical order.

SPEECH.PARA: I adopt everything that has been said by Senator Button about Senator Bonner. Senator Bonner was unique. It may be some time before another Aboriginal Australian is in this Parliament. If it is I, and I am sure many others, will regret that fact. Neville Bonner really distinguished himself and was a very fine representative of the people about whom he felt very deeply. I think it is instructive for all of us to read Neville Bonner's biography. It tells of a childhood the like of which none of us would have experienced. The fact that he came to this place with the dignity, talent and ability that he had was a great tribute to him. I think it was also a great tribute to the spirit of all of the Aboriginal people of Australia.

While I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs no one could have been more helpful or more understanding-at times he was a terrible spur and scourge-than Senator Bonner. I wish to place on public record my gratitude to him for his friendship and tolerance during that time. The field of Aboriginal affairs was often difficult for Neville. He had ambitions for his people which sometimes we did not-indeed no government could ever-live up to. I really appreciated his contribution in that area. In a sense that contribution was symbolised by his bringing into this place the legislation for the establishment of the Aboriginal Development Commission, which put a very large number of programs of great value into Aboriginal hands. I think that symbolised the way in which he affected the thinking of us all, certainly on our side of politics. He leaves with my very great regret. Indeed, I think we all regret that he left the Parliament and fought his last campaign as an Independent. He certainly has left a lot of friends, and indeed all of us on this side of the chamber feel that he is our very close friend.

Senator Martyr was much more briefly in the Senate. I must say that when I think of his leaving I am reminded of the words which I think Senator Wheeldon used in respect of Senator Greenwood when he died. Senator Wheeldon reminded us that Senator Greenwood had been an important spokesman for a section of the community who sometimes had been under-represented and whose views had not been heard. He pointed out that many people would miss the advocacy which Senator Greenwood brought. In the same way I think John Martyr had a particular constituency which will feel his departure very strongly. The particular concerns he had related to issues such as the family, abortion, family law-a range of things. I do not need to remind the Senate of the matters on which he was passionate. I think he represented a point of view which is perhaps under- represented at times in this place. I know there will be many who will miss his voice here. He was not always a comfortable companion because of the strength of his views but I think that some of the views he would have put forward on the family law legislation, including questions of marriage contracts and so on, might have led to a lengthier, but perhaps improved, debate.

Senator Thomas was on a team with me on a number of occasions and was a very good friend and colleague. He will be particularly missed because of the extraordinary service he provided to rural and outback Western Australia. I of course agree with the very complimentary words used by Senator Button, and I adopt them on behalf of the Opposition, but I draw attention to the great length of time which Senator Thomas spent travelling in the remoter parts of Western Australia during each parliamentary recess. It was a unique contribution. Wherever I went in remote Western Australia during the last election campaign I received expressions of appreciation for Andrew Thomas's representation of those people. All Western Australian senators will know how difficult it is to serve a State of one million square miles, and I think Andrew, more than any other person, took up that challenge with great zest. I do not think his political ambitions are over, and I certainly hope he will be back with us.

Mr President, Senator Sir Harold Young adopted the most honoured position in the Senate, the position you now hold. He had the respect of us all and he goes with our very great regret. He regretted the early election because it ended his career a year or so earlier than I think he would have wished. For his sake I regret that too. If I may add a personal note again, I was Deputy Whip to Harold Young when I first became a senator and I was able to watch him at close quarters working as Whip. At that time, of course, he worked under Reg Withers as Leader. I learned of his very great qualities, his terrific ability to make friends and his great generosity of spirit. He was generous to me and I think to all his colleagues. Harold will be missed in a personal sense by many, if not all, of us. He certainly has my gratitude for what he did in this place both for the Senate and for me personally.
I turn now to the members of the Opposition. Senator Keeffe was-

TALK.START.PARA: —The former Opposition.

—I am sorry; I regret that. I turn now to those senators who were in the Opposition. When I look down the list I certainly know that they were in the Opposition. They opposed with very great vigour and strength the measures that the Government was putting forward or failing to put forward. Senator Keeffe was capable of getting into many scraps in this place. His public record is in the Senate Hansard and is well known to all. Again I do not differ from the views which were expressed by Senator Button. I merely add to what Senator Button has said that when Senator Keeffe wrote to me and in the discussions which I had with him in the corridors and in my office, I found him to be a man of immense courtesy. It was always very pleasant to receive representations from Senator Keeffe as long as they were not in this chamber when it was a very uncomfortable business. I record his deep and abiding interest in Aboriginal affairs for which I was responsible for some time and the constructive way in which he approached the subject particularly when we were out of this place and out of the public disputation which necessarily occurs between government and opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLaren was a man rather similar in quality to Senator Keeffe. I acknowledge and endorse all the comments made by Senator Button. I found in Senator McLaren an assiduous attention to his constituents' concerns not merely in this chamber but also out of the chamber. In my capacity as a former Minister he was one of those people whom I saw very frequently. He was very strong in the views which he put. He also responded very well to the efforts that were made on behalf of his constituents and himself. Whilst I will not miss him at the Estimates committee debates or, I suspect, in any of the debates in this place, I certainly will miss him around Parliament House.

I knew Senator Mulvihill less well but it seems to me that his contribution was peculiar to him. His interests were very evident to us. He was a man of great passion. When he took up a cause with passion it was very wise sometimes to step aside while he went past. His representations were of the sort which made it impossible to do other than give very careful attention to them. I join with Senator Button in paying tribute to what he did in this place. I think he represented the interests about which he was particularly concerned very well and with great passion.

In a sense we should all regret losing Senator Siddons because he represented one of the scarcest commodities in this place; that is, a person with independent business experience. I think those sorts of people represent the scarcest occupation group in the Parliament. Senator Siddons was not at all representative of business generally. He had some views which he expressed passionately-industrial democracy has been mentioned. I express the view that, in losing Senator Siddons, we should perhaps not merely regret losing him as an individual but we should regret the loss of a representative of the business community, the concerns and problems of which I think are often inadequately understood all round this chamber and in the other place as well. Senator Siddons had run a substantial Australian corporation and he had a working knowledge of the virtues and vices of protection and the problems on the shop floor from the employer's side. Of course there are many on the Government side who have experience from the trade union side rather than the employer side. I hope that all parties, be they the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party or the Australian Democrats, might send to this Parliament more people with the working background of Senator Siddons.

It is amazing how we all improve in character and become much more likeable the moment we leave this place. The Government Whip is quite clearly prepared to see me go very soon. He might even offer the hand of friendship if I do. On behalf of Opposition senators I wish all those retired senators well and express our thanks to them for the contributions they have made in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in paying tribute to the departing senators. I thank both Senator Button and Senator Chaney for their generous remarks about my erstwhile colleague, Senator Siddons. I too would like to make a short personal mention of each of them in alphabetical order starting with my friend of many years, Neville Bonner. To assess this man's worth there is no need to go to his performance although his performance while he was an elected representative was impressive indeed. After due consideration, I say that had I had his beginning, been poor, been black and been raised in ignorance with his lack of opportunity, I would not have come within any distance of his achievements. He achieved despite fearsome handicaps not of his making that were placed in his way. The fact that he was able to overcome those massive handicaps is a tribute to the great stature of this man who is no longer with us. The Senate will be a poorer place for not having Neville Bonner in it.

SPEECH.PARA: I had an affection for Jim Keeffe. He sat next to me and enlivened dreary debates with jolly interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jolly?

—When it comes to talking about Jim Keeffe 'jolly' is a good word. He had an indefatigable sense of humour with which I did not always agree but at least he tried to be funny and introduce some levity into this sometimes dreary place. The last thing that one could accuse Geoff McLaren of would be having a sense of humour. I am told that he did in committees and elsewhere but it was very difficult to discover in this chamber, particularly if one was at the receiving end of it as I often was. Notwithstanding that, there would be unanimity in this place that his tenacity made a valuable contribution to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: John Martyr is another man of whom I can claim to have been a close personal friend. In the 23 years that I have been in politics I do not know anyone who would have had less in common with my political beliefs, ideology or almost any subject at all except perhaps sport. John Martyr was an extreme, avid, fanatic right-winger and he was very proud of that. The extraordinary thing was that, notwithstanding this massive difference in our philosophies, we were very close personal friends. John Martyr had a great capacity to love and to be loved. Those who had the privilege of getting to know him would have found out the true meaning of affection and love. I have abiding, deep and compassionate memories of John Martyr, particularly when I used to captain the parliamentary cricket team against the Press. Inevitably, the only one brave or foolish enough to accept my request to be wicket keeper was John Martyr. Inevitably, within 10 minutes of the start of every cricket match, he was covered in blood as a result of a gashed eye, forehead or whatever. Notwithstanding that, he took it all with good humour.

Tony Mulvihill and I were friends for a long time. We shared pleasant jibes with each other about the relative values of rugby league-if that is a game one can still mention-and Australian rules football. He was always pleasant, good humoured and friendly. I did not know Andrew Thomas very well but I knew him to be a man of principle. I remember very well a conflict of principle between his philosophy and his holding of office within the Liberal Party in this Parliament -he chose the principle by resigning as Deputy Government Whip. Any person who does that has my admiration. I pay that tribute to him.

I pay a tribute to Sir Harold Young who was a close personal friend of mine dating back to my Liberal Party days. I journeyed with him overseas on some occasions. He was a pleasant companion. I believe he lifted the already high stature of the presidency of this Senate, or at least maintained its status. He was a great fighter for the Parliament and the Senate against the greedy clutches of the Executive. I think all honourable senators should thank him for that. I remember with affection and admiration his tenure of office.

I have left my colleague John Siddons till last so that I can pay a special tribute and say how very sorry I am that he was not returned at the last election. Senator Chaney was generous in referring to him as being one of the few public industrialists to have been elected to this place in recent years. I say to all honourable senators, particularly honourable senators who have now become Ministers with newfound power: 'Do not demean the office of a member of parliament by any shape or form because there is nobody-the Press or the public- who will lift the office of a member of parliament'. If we demean it ourselves, by the actions of the Executive or the actions of the Parliament, we will lessen the chances of again attracting people of the calibre of John Siddons.

I will explain further what I mean. John Siddons was the executive chairman and chairman of directors of a company employing 1,500 to 2,000 people. He was on a high salary and on a very lucrative superannuation scheme but he wanted to serve the Parliament. I will not embarass John Siddons by disclosing what he lost permanently by choosing to serve as a member of parliament, but he did so choose . He was elected for six years and, in fact, served less than two years. As from 5 March the John Siddonses of this world are out there and nobody gives a damn. If that is the way we are going to treat people who undertake personal sacrifice to serve, we are not going to be attracting to this Parliament the leaders of industry or leaders of commerce whom I believe it desperately needs. I get tired sometimes when some of us demean ourselves by using the cheap grandstanding trick of going to the people and saying: 'We will halve our salaries or cut our salaries by 10 per cent or 20 per cent'. This is a meaningless thing. What are we doing? All we are doing is dragging ourselves and this institution down and making it less likely that big people, big men and big women, will offer themselves for the service of the nation.

I will very briefly compliment John Siddons on the industrial democracy Bill which he championed. Only God and the Australian Democrats know how many times he championed it because we were in the party room with him. He attempted to save the Community Youth Support Scheme. He worked hard and was one of the initiators in saving the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. He was active in respect of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill and was a great champion for the maintenance of the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. He was a champion also of Australian manufacturing industry. He recognised small business and put a great amount of work into presenting to this Senate alternative budgets in 1981-82 which hindsight has proven to be brilliant in their concept and correct in economic terms. He championed the abolishment of an undistributed profits tax which the Government finally accepted and he brought into the Senate an electoral Bill which is now going to be taken up by the new Government.

I conclude by saying that although John Siddons was a giant of industry and an employer he was the most passionate in our party meetings for the Democrats to join with the Australian Labor Party to stop, above all, the then Government taking the unemployment benefit from the spouses of striking workers. He said that was an act of unmitigated cruelty which would make people suffer when they could not help the situation. I remember remarking on this fact to myself at the time-that a chairman of directors of a company employing 2,000 workers could take off his coat as chairman of directors, put himself in the kitchen of a household where a worker was on strike, address his mind to the problems of the wife and say: 'We cannot allow this woman to have her unemployment benefit taken away'. Such was the humility of this man. On behalf of my Australian Democrat colleagues, I pay him that tribute.
