TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Handbook also points out that Tony Mulvihill was elected Assistant Secretary of the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Labor Party in 1957 and served in that position until 1964. This emphasises the fact that he gave a lifetime of service to the Australian Labor Party and to the Labor movement. One other point which I should make about Tony Mulvihill and which is mentioned in the Parliamentary Handbook is that he was the shadow Minister for the environment during 1976 and 1977. It is fair to say that he was perhaps the first person to make conservation an issue in the Labor Party in my State of New South Wales. I can remember that years ago he would rise at conferences and state councils and start talking about the Cape Barren goose, the red kangaroo or dingoes. We would all laugh at him. But by the time he left the Parliament, he was still speaking about those things at our conferences and nobody was laughing at him. I remember when he first spoke about the Kakadu National Park. I had never heard of it. But he spoke with such strength and feeling on the issue that a number of us then began to be more and more involved in these issues. I am sure that by the time Tony Mulvihill left the Senate, the work that he had done in conservation had had a great effect on all of us.

SPEECH.PARA: Tony was a trade unionist of the old school. He was a member of the Australian Railways Union. Whenever his biography was put in any publication he always mentioned that he was the captain of the tug-of-war team from the railway workshops. Apparently, that was one of the highlights of Tony's career. He was a sportsman. He played rugby league for Eastern Suburbs in Sydney. It is a tough sport and, in some ways, Tony was a tough person. He kept his contacts with the trade union movement. It would be fair to say that no senator worked harder in our State for the trade union movement than Tony Mulvihill. He was not one who sought the limelight. He is the minute secretary at our annual conference. I cannot think of a more onerous and back-breaking job, but Tony does it year after year. He is also the minute secretary for our State council. It did not matter whether a rural conference or a meeting of the party was held anywhere, Tony Mulvihill would be there, doing those sorts of jobs which did not put him in the limelight.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he loved his dog.

—I am getting to that. All honourable senators on both sides of the chamber would be interested to know that since Tony Mulvihill left the Senate-he has retired in one sense-one of the first things he did was to open an office in the Trades Hall in Sydney. He continues to do constituent work for the trade unions and the migrant community in New South Wales. All of us who knew him realised that he had a great interest in, and a great love for, Yugoslavia. He visited the country many times. The Yugoslav Government decorated him for his services to the Yugoslav community in Australia and he was very proud of it. I remember making an official visit to Yugoslavia. I was staggered by the number of people not only in the National Parliament but also in the different State parliaments around the country who knew of, and spoke about, Tony Mulvihill and the work that he had done for the Yugoslav community in Australia. Of course, he did a lot of work for the Greek and Italian communities too, and particularly for the Spanish speaking communities in Sydney. The South American communities had tended to be ignored. If they had a champion in this Senate, it was Senator Tony Mulvihill. He was one of the real characters of the Senate and he will be missed. Honourable senators who heard his farewell speech, when he got square on somebody who had kicked his dog years ago, will never forget the speech. Anyone who was not here at the time should obtain a copy of Hansard to read one of the greatest speeches ever made in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Tony held strong views on many things. I could spend all night telling a number of stories about him, but I will tell only a couple. I well remember hearing the story about how he got very upset in a debate and called former Senator McManus from the Australian Democratic Labor Party-he did not like the DLP-a bludger. Somebody took a point of order and asked him to withdraw. When he spoke to the then President he said that he would not withdraw and that Senator McManus was worse than a bludger, he was a Melbourne bludger. I will always remember another story about Tony when he was campaigning in Tasmania for the ALP. We were having a drink at the end of the day. One of the voters in the bar said that he had always wanted to meet Senator Tony Mulvihill, so we took him around to meet him. He said: 'Senator, you're the person who saved the Cape Barren goose, aren't you ?' Tony Mulvihill swelled with pride and said: 'That's right'. The man said, 'I' ve been waiting to meet you for years. There are thousands of the damn things now and they eat everything that I try to grow on my farm', which deflated Tony a little at the time.

I got only 10 minutes' or a quarter of an hour's notice that I had to make this speech tonight. I have probably omitted many things. I have incorporated the page from the Parliamentary Handbook in the Hansard because I know that if I have forgotten something, Tony Mulvihill will get square. I do not want him to get square with me the way he got square with the person mentioned in his farewell speech. Mr President, I know that I speak on your behalf, and on behalf of the Minister for Veteran's Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, Senator Childs and Senator Richardson, who has just taken Tony Mulvihill's place in the Senate. As I said, he put in a lifetime of service to the Australian Labor Party and all of us wish him well in his retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly about one of the colleagues we are referring to today. I am sure all of us would like to say a few words about all of them, but the leaders have done that. I rise to put on record a few comments about a former colleague from Queensland, Senator Neville Bonner. Senator Bonner will be sorely missed by this Parliament. As an Aborigine -it should be noted that he has his place in history as the first Aborgine ever elected to any parliament in Australia and the only Aborigine ever elected to the national Parliament-he brought much valuable expertise and feeling to a vexatious area of policy in the years that he was here. However, he did much more than that. His contribution to party forums and to various Ministers over the years on that subject was very particular. I believe his very presence in the Parliament had a value in itself. I am not suggesting for one minute that he was in any way an example of tokenism, that lower standards were set for him than were set for anyone else, because they were not. He went through the most rigorous preselection procedures in 1970, 1971, 1972 and so on, and came out on top because he was the best candidate and an outstanding senator. Nevertheless, I believe he was a great inspiration to Aboriginal people because he was so visible and so well known. They certainly all knew that he had aspired to, and achieved the status of, membership of the national Parliament. The fact that he was here meant a great deal to Aborigines, giving them hope. I hope that the fact that he is no longer here means that Aborigines will not lose faith and will not come to the conclusion that there is not a place for them in the system .

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure many honourable senators have read his biography and know the story of his birth, his childhood and his adulthood prior to entering political activity. I found it a most enlightening book to read in terms of just how gross was the discrimination against Aborigines in Australia in previous decades. The fact that Neville Bonner lived the life that he did-it is described so simply and so clearly in that biography-and came through it as a great human being, a man of great warmth and without bitterness for what he had suffered is a tribute to him as a human being. I remember in particular one section which describes when he was living with his grandmother in what is referred to as a blacks camp under lantana shrubs. He spent a good part of his formative years living under those sorts of conditions. Just what sort of person makes the transition from that sort of moulding in childhood to this place? The answer is: A very great person indeed. He is an outstanding human being. As all of us know, he is a thorough gentleman and, very proudly, a Christian gentleman. He brought great insight and understanding to all the subjects that he tackled here. People naturally identified him with the Aboriginal cause and he was in fact criticised for being preoccupied with the subject. There were those who said that he was a senator for Aborigines and not a senator for Queensland. Neville Bonner never defended himself against that criticism, and he could have so easily. The fact was that he made a major contribution in a number of areas of national policy.

He was very closely involved with all types of disadvantaged groups, as he saw them. His work for pensioners is certainly something that pensioners know about, even if other Australians do not when they focus only on what he had to say about Aborigines. He made a very valuable contribution to this country in his travels overseas in a variety of capacities, not the least of which was through the agency of World Vision. He is a patron of World Vision and has done much work in that area. I think a large number of us will remember some quite outstanding work he did on television during the International Year of the Child when he talked about 'For the Love of Kids' and made an appeal to all Australians to make sure that we are worthy of the children of this nation.

Neville Bonner will continue to be a very important Australian. I said a few minutes ago that he has his place in the history books, and nobody will ever take that away from him. In the years to come I think people will look back with some amazement, as we become more distant from the sorts of conditions he suffered as an Aborigine, at his achievements and recognise what incredible personal qualities he has. I hope that we can look forward to seeing him continue to contribute to Australia. There are too few Aborigines like Neville Bonner who have his ability to cope with both aboriginality and living in a very much westernised society. He is an important bridge for Aborigines and for white Australians in understanding what they must do to make sure that we achieve the sort of Australia we would like for people of all colours. I look forward, as I am sure do all his colleagues here, to the continuing contribution that he will make. It is highly valuable, and I know that the history books will treat Neville Bonner very generously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about Geoff McLaren on behalf of South Australian senators. We all know that he is a great terrier for and fossicker of information. But many people do not know about the very hard work which Geoff McLaren did in the country areas of South Australia. Like former Senator Thomas, Geoff travelled very widely and represented everyone he came across. Many of those people never voted for the Australian Labor Party, but Geoff always represented all the people. That is to his credit. He will be remembered in many areas. In South Australia quite a number of functions have been held in honour of Geoff McLaren for the work he did in country electorates. Some honourable senators opposite may be pleased to see him go so that the Estimates committees can get through their work, but we on this side appreciated Geoff's great contribution and his very hard work in South Australia. The wine industry and all the rural industries will most certainly miss him. I agree with the remarks made about Geoff McLaren and the other senators who have retired, but the list is too long to go through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join very warmly with all the remarks that have been made about all our former colleagues, but I would like to mention particularly Neville Bonner and Sir Harold Young. Neville Bonner has left a lesser known institution in this Parliament with something of a constitutional crisis. That organisation is a committee called the brandy committee which has forthrightly represented in appropriate places the brandy industry, which is chiefly sited in South Australia. He was the last chairman of that committee and , having left this place, leaves us with no alternative machinery with which to elect a new chairman. So it looks as though we will have to re-form the committee. The members of that committee will realise the contribution that he made to the industry and his performance on behalf of all senators in ensuring that that industry's future remains prosperous in one way or another.

SPEECH.PARA: In the time that I have known my very great friend Sir Harold Young, which is something like 16 years, he has always been one of the most pleasant personalities-certainly a person with whom all of us had some identification of personal feeling. To my mind he was one of the most popular politicians in South Australia. Whenever we travelled together throughout the State, however remote the locality, he would either have a relative in the immediate vicinity or be well known to people in the area. I think he was one of the outstanding contributors in this place to the welfare of South Australians generally. Apart from Sir Harold's electoral activities, he represented a very great constituency in the State-the farming industries. He was very active for many years in the farmers and graziers associations in the State. He was recognised by being appointed to and representing several committees and organisations at the highest level. He will be remembered for that. He will also be remembered right across the State as having served his State with great capacity, enormous skill and great distinction. I have been asked by all my South Australian colleagues to say those words also on their behalf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to pay a brief tribute to three of my former colleagues whom I am sure will not mind me calling them friends-Geoff McLaren, Tony Mulvihill and Jim Keeffe. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and others have spoken of all of those who left last year, and I endorse all that has been said about them. I confine myself to the three I have mentioned simply because of the particular contributions they made to the Northern Territory. Others have spoken, and yet others may speak, of their personal qualities. I endorse what has been said and what may be said but do not want to repeat it, because we do not want to spend too long on the adjournment tonight. Before I mention the contributions that they made to the Northern Territory, can I just say that, for the short time I was Whip while they were members of the Senate, the three of them fell into the category of real Whips' mates. They were always ready to step in at a moment's notice and hold the fort if a speaker was required. They were good aggressive speakers in the best sense of that word and from their early days in this place, I understand, adopted that sort of stance.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me speak firstly of Geoff McLaren because he took a keen interest in the Northern Territory right from the time that he came into the Senate. In fact, I understand that before I came here in 1975 he was jokingly referred to by his colleagues as 'the senator for the Northern Territory'. This was attested to by the fact that he took up many issues for people living in the Northern Territory . The reason he was able to do this was, of course, that he visited us many times in the Nothern Territory. It was a great joy to both my wife and me that on many occasions both he and Mrs McLaren were able to stay with us in our home. He also visited many times to help with campaigns. All of the people he met as we knocked on doors and campaigned throughout the Northern Territory were impressed by his enthusiasm and basically, I suppose, by his energy, but also by his knowledge of the Labor movement, from both the trade union arm and the political arm.

He served, as we all know, on the joint Committee for the Northern Territory from 1973. He helped draft both the initial report and the report which was put out after Cyclone Tracy in case any amendments to the initial report were needed . I think the contribution he made was invaluable because of his background in the Northern Territory. He probably knew more spots and spoke to more people in the Northern Territory than any other member of the Committee. I certainly do not wish to denigrate their efforts, but Geoff made a great contribution because he knew what was needed in the Northern Territory.

I must mention also his contribution to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. He was a most effective Committee member because he was able to draw on a very wide background and because, as has been indicated by some of the former speakers, he was quite merciless, if you like, in his pursuit of information, whether the information was from a witness, a Minister or a member of a department. He did this with a certain grace and charm. People always ended up friendly with Geoff McLaren after he had been quite strong in his questioning of them. I know that he would want me to mention the work of our former Chairman , Senator Andrew Thomas, who was a thorough gentleman and who gave us a great deal of leadership on that Committee. I join with him in saying that we are sorry that Andrew has not returned to join us here. Geoff's name is recorded on a plaque at the Post Office at Tennant Creek, which he opened for the Government in 1974, I believe it was. But I think that his more effective record is in the hearts of the Northern Territory people who remember him.

Tony Mulvihill also visited the Northern Territory and helped campaign on a couple of occasions. I remember one of those stories that seem to proliferate about Tony. It concerns the advice he gave me as we moved off to address the first union meeting that I addressed as a candidate in the Northern Territory. He took me aside and said: 'One piece of advice I will give you: Don't stop talking; don't give them a chance to butt in'. Of course, anyone who heard Tony with the union movement would know that he followed his own counsel very well. I had never known anyone who was able to speak without drawing breath. He is also remembered for his contribution to the debates on environmental issues. He was, as our colleague Senator Sibraa has mentioned, a great lover of Kakadu National Park and spoke very strongly on the need for Kakadu National Park to be set aside. He was always very anxious to protect the flora and fauna of Australia. We shared an interest in dingoes and their place in the community. Tony was a warm, caring person who always was ready to assist junior colleagues. I certainly valued the assistance which he gave me when I first came to this place .

Jim Keeffe was another frequent visitor to the Northern Territory. He came to the Northern Territory because of his interest in the Aboriginal people. It is fair to say that Jim has Aboriginal friends all over the Northern Territory. I was fortunate to serve with him on our party's national platform committee on a number of occasions. I was impressed then by his understanding of Aboriginal people, the knowledge he had of Aboriginal folklore and the warm, friendly relationships which he built up with Aboriginal people all over Australia as we went around. I think it is a tribute to him that the present Aboriginal affairs policy owes a great deal to the contribution which he made over the years.

I thank these three for the contributions they have made to the Northern Territory and assure them-I am sure they would like to be assured of this-that they are remembered with affection in the Northern Territory, and the role they played is very much appreciated by us up there. I look forward to enjoying fellowship with all of those who left last year and endorse the wishes that have been extended for an enjoyable retirement for all of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak in this part of the proceedings. I was sorely tempted, however, to wait until the adjournment debate because my comments will be specifically limited to ex-Senator Geoff McLaren. It would seem appropriate that, considering Geoff's use of the adjournment debate while he was a member of this place--
—Don't worry; it is the adjournment debate.

—Is it? In that case I am doing the right thing. His absence will surely be noted by the Senate. I am sure that when it comes to processes of the Senate, such as petitions, notices of motions or whatever, many of us who were here with Geoff McLaren will remember the skills and the cunning that he adopted in applying himself to the use of Senate Standing Orders and procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: Geoff McLaren was elected to this place in 1970. As he says, if it were not for his success at that time John Bannon would not now be Premier of South Australia . Geoff got in on preselection before John Bannon in 1969. Once elected he approached his task here most assiduously and devoted himself to pursuing not only the interests of his electors but also the interests, principles and policies of the Australian Labor Party through and through. If there is one thing that can be said about Geoff McLaren it is that he had solidarity with the working people of Australia, the labour movement and, more than that, all South Australians, wherever they lived, wherever they came from.

As Senator Elstob said earlier, Senator McLaren based himself in a country electorate and was in many ways a country senator for South Australia. He was in fact, for much of the time that he was representing South Australia, the only Federal member of parliament who had an office in the country. He made sure that members of the National Country Party in this place took note of that point. He will be missed, not only in the Riverland and areas such as Mount Gambier where his presence was often felt; but especially in Murray Bridge, where he had his office. As my colleague Senator Maguire said, it will be interesting now to keep a tab on the Murray Bridge Post Office and the reduction of work which now might take place because of Geoff McLaren's absence from the Senate.

As I said earlier, his approach to the Standing Orders and procedures was one that I learnt a lot from, having had the pleasure to sit with him for approximately two years. He knew what could and could not be done within the Standing Orders; I suggest he was able to get away with doing both. I do not wish to say any more, but tie myself in with the comments made by Senator Elstob in respect of Senator McLaren. In doing so I ask that it be noted that both Senator Elstob and I are making these comments on behalf of all Labor senators from South Australia.
